Review Advanced preparation and application of bimetallic materials in lithium-sulfur batteries: A review Yongbing Jin Nanping Deng ⁎ Yanan Li Hao Wang Meiling Zhang ⁎ Weimin Kang ⁎ Bowen Cheng State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes School of Textile Science and Engineering Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract In this review, we comprehensively summarize the mechanism of suppressing “shuttle effect” of LiPSs in LSBs, the selection of bimetallic materials and novel structural design, as well as the development prospects and future researching directions of bimetallic materials for high performance LSBs. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered highly promising as next-generation energy storage systems due to high theoretical capacity (2600 W h kg−1) and energy density (1675 mA h g−1) as well as the abundant natural reserves, low cost of elemental sulfur, and environmentally friendly properties. However, several challenges impede its commercialization including low conductivity of sulfur itself, the severe “shuttle effect” caused by lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) during charge–discharge processes, volume expansion effects and sluggish reaction kinetics. As a solution, polar metal particles and their compounds have been introduced as the main hosts for sulfur cathode due to their robust catalytic activity and adsorption capability, effectively suppressing the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Bimetallic alloys and their compounds with multi-functional properties exhibit remarkable electrochemical performance more readily when compared to single-metal materials. Well-designed bimetallic materials demonstrate larger specific surface areas and richer active sites, enabling simultaneous high adsorption capability and strong catalytic properties. The synergistic effect of the “adsorption-catalysis” sites accelerates the adsorption-diffusion-conversion process of LiPSs, ultimately achieving a long-lasting Li-S battery. Herein, the latest progress and performance of bimetallic materials in cathodes, separators, and interlayers of Li-S batteries are systematically reviewed. Firstly, the principles and challenges of Li-S batteries are briefly analyzed. Then, various mechanisms for suppressing “shuttle effects” of LiPSs are emphasized at the microscale. Subsequently, the performance parameters of various bimetallic materials are comprehensively summarized, and some improvement strategies are proposed based on these findings. Finally, the future prospects of bimetallic materials are discussed, with the hope of providing profound insights for the rational design and manufacturing of high-performance bimetallic materials for LSBs. Keywords Bimetallic materials Lithium-sulfur batteries Effectively suppress shuttle effect of LiPSs Significantly improve reaction kinetics Exceptionally long lifespan 1 Introduction The exponential growth of the global population, coupled with technological advancements and improved economic standards, has resulted in a substantial increase in global energy demand. Currently, fossil fuels such as coal, oil and natural gas play a critical role in meeting this demand. However, the extensive extraction and utilization of these non-renewable resources have led to the depletion of fossil energy reserves. Additionally, the combustion of fossil fuels emits greenhouse gases and pollutants, contributing to severe environmental pollution and climate change. Consequently, the development of advanced renewable energy technologies has emerged as an urgent global priority [1–3]. Over the past few decades, there has been a persistent quest for renewable energy sources as viable alternatives to fossil fuels. Prominent examples include wind energy, solar energy, tidal energy and geothermal energy. However, these energy sources possess inherent intermittency, and their extraction often necessitates the deployment of numerous large-scale generation facilities. For fully unlocking the potential of these energy sources, the robust energy storage systems are imperative. Consequently, in order to transition from a fossil fuel-dominated energy economy to one centered around renewable technologies, it is of utmost importance to substantially augment the capabilities for large-scale, cost-effective energy conversion and storage [4,5]. Against the backdrop of an era characterized by information and networking, the rapid advancement of electric vehicles (EVs) and portable smart electronic devices has necessitated the development of energy storage systems with enhanced capacity and high energy density [6,7]. In the domain of high-performance electric vehicles, several governments including China, Japan, South Korea, France, the United Kingdom and the United States, have implemented policies to encourage the adoption and sales of electric cars [8]. Various organizations concur in their estimation that by 2050, electric vehicles will constitute 60% of the total passenger car market. The projection will further amplify the market demand for energy storage systems with enhanced capacity and high energy density [9]. Batteries especially for secondary batteries are widely recognized as one of the most prevalent forms of energy storage systems. Currently, the battery market comprises two main categories: primary batteries, such as alkaline batteries and zinc-manganese batteries, and rechargeable batteries, including nickel–chromium batteries and lithium-ion batteries. Among these, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have gained significant global popularity since Sony company introduced graphite anode lithium-ion batteries. The result is primarily attributed to their remarkable features including a low self-discharge rate, high operating voltage and long cycle life. LIBs have consistently maintained a competitive advantage over other battery types due to their affordability, stability and extended cycle life. As a result, they have found widespread applications in portable electronic devices, transportation and stationary energy storage [10,11]. The typical structure of LIBs consists of several components: cathode electrode (such as LiCoO2, LiNi2O4 or LiFePO4), anode electrode (carbon materials and composite carbon materials), separator (polyolefin-based materials) and electrolyte (typically ether-based or ester-based liquid electrolyte). The current technology behind LIBs is based on intercalation reactions, wherein lithium ions shuttle back and forth between the electrodes during charge and discharge processes. During the charging process, lithium ions deintercalate from the cathode electrode, traverse through the electrolyte, and intercalate into the anode electrode. As a result, the anode electrode becomes lithium-rich. This process is reversed during discharge process. These charge and discharge processes primarily involve the reversible adsorption of lithium ions and electrons within the solid structure of the electrodes with minimal structural changes. However, this characteristic limits the charge storage capacity and energy density of LIBs [12]. The utilization of transition metal oxides as cathode electrode materials in intercalation reactions typically results in an energy density which reaches a maximum of approximately 350 W h kg−1 [13]. Theoretically, increasing the battery voltage can indeed further enhance energy density. However, the current liquid electrolytes available face challenges in raising the operating voltage of the cathode electrode beyond 4.3 V. Numerous researchers have explored strategies such as modifications in electrode materials and advancements in liquid electrolytes to improve charge storage capacity. Nevertheless, these approaches still fall short of meeting the rapidly growing demands of current devices due to traditional battery materials closing to the upper limit of theoretical values. While anodes have brought transformative advancements in various technologies, the energy density has been already approaching its theoretical maximum, posing challenges in meeting the ever-increasing performance requirements in practical applications. Consequently, some researchers are actively searching for alternative lithium-based electrochemical energy storage systems offering superior performance [14]. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have attracted considerable attention from academia and industry alike due to their high theoretical energy density of 2600 W h kg−1 and ultrahigh theoretical discharge capacity of 1675 mA h g−1. The fundamental structure of LSBs involves sulfur serving as the cathode electrode and lithium as the anode electrode. The Gibbs energy associated with the Li/S reaction is approximately five times higher than that of lithium-ion systems, as determined through theoretical energy calculations [15]. In contrast to the “Li intercalation/de-intercalation” mechanism in traditional LIBs, LSBs rely on a multi-electron reversible redox reaction between metallic lithium and S8. During discharge process, S8 is reduced to various forms of LiPSs or Li2S2/Li2S. Typically, there are two discharge platform in the discharge process of LSBs [16]. The platform at 2.1–2.4 V corresponds to the transition from solid-state S8 to soluble long-chain LiPSs. The capacity contributed by the reactions in this stage accounts for approximately 25% of the total capacity of LSBs. Subsequently, the reactions in the second platform at 1.6–2.1 V contribute to about 75% of the total capacity of LSBs, corresponding to the transformation from soluble short-chain LiPSs to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S. The charging process of LSBs is the reversible reaction of the discharge process: Solid Li2S is firstly transformed into insoluble Li2S2, then into soluble long-chain LiPSs, and finally transformed into solid sulfur. The substantial morphological structure changes from solid-liquid-solid greatly enhance the energy density of LSBs [17,18]. As shown in Fig. 1 (A), compared to LIBs, LSBs can offer several advantages, including higher theoretical energy density, non-toxicity and low cost. They represent a crucial development goal in the field of next-generation efficient energy storage. Furthermore, sulfur species as a byproduct of the petroleum industry enables the low-cost production of LSBs. These advantages position LSBs with broad prospects in next generation of electrochemical energy storage devices. Despite the prominent advantages of LSBs, their commercialization process still faces significant obstacles as depicted in Fig. 1(B) [19,20]. Firstly, poor conductivity of elemental sulfur and LiPSs hampers the utilization of their inherent high specific capacity, thereby undermining the high-rate performance of the batteries [21]. Furthermore, during the charge–discharge processes, the intermediate products of LSBs, known as LiPSs, have a propensity to dissolve in ether-based electrolytes. The formed phenomenon not only leads to the detachment of active materials from the cell electrode, reducing the effective utilization of these materials, but also causes the LiPSs to shuttle back and forth between electrodes, giving rise to the detrimental “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. As a result, the overall electrochemical performance of LSBs deteriorates [15]. Thirdly, the significant volume changes of elemental sulfur during the cycle processes can result in the detachment of active materials from the electrode, thereby affecting the stability of the cathode materials. Moreover, the non-uniform deposition of lithium on the lithium electrode during cycling also can give rise to the formation of serious lithium dendrites. These lithium dendrites have the potential to dissolve, fracture and detach from the electrode, leading to the formation of “dead lithium”. Consequently, this process significantly diminishes the battery capacity and cycle life. Additionally, the continuous growth of lithium dendrites poses a safety hazard because they can puncture the separator, thereby causing short circuits and even explosions [22]. To mitigate the aforementioned drawbacks of LSBs, some researchers have adopted various strategies from the aspects of cathode electrode structure and composition, electrolyte optimization, separator modification and anode electrode interface design to optimize the electrochemical performance of LSBs (Fig. 1). Over the past decade, significant progresses have been made by coupling sulfur cathodes with various carbonaceous materials such as carbon nanotubes [23], biomass-derived carbons [24], graphene oxides [25], g-C3N4 [26] and porous carbons [27] to address these issues. However, non-polar carbon materials cannot provide sufficient active sites to strongly anchor polar LiPSs, and the weak van der Waals interactions between them fail to effectively suppress the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Therefore, nitrogen doping has been introduced into carbonaceous materials (N-C) to increase polarity and facilitate the immobilization of LiPSs, leading to remarkable breakthroughs. Unfortunately, due to the low doping level of heteroatoms, the severe capacity decay problem remains challenging to overcome. As a result, some researchers have introduced polar metal compounds which can chemically adsorb LiPSs to a certain extent through the Lewis acid-base interactions between transition metal cations and LiPSs, providing excellent chemical adsorption sites. After years of research, significant progress has been made in Li-S batteries, with remarkable improvements in various performance aspects of cell electrodes and separators. However, the electrolyte/sulfur ratio (E/S) applied in such batteries is typically high (20 μL mg−1), which severely limits the practical energy density of LSBs [28]. Therefore, for further advancing the practical applications of LSBs, it is highly necessary to explore the design principles and researching trends of LSBs under low E/S conditions. As is well known, he limited wetting of the surface of the host material under low E/S conditions results in a contradiction between high sulfur utilization and long cycling stability. For ensuring high sulfur utilization under low E/S conditions, many researchers have utilized electrolytes with high solubility for all sulfur species. However, the fully dissolved LiPSs cannot be effectively adsorbed by the relatively low surface area of the host materials. These un-adsorbed LiPSs in the lean electrolyte also cause significant concentration gradients, leading to severe “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and poor cycling performance. As shown in Fig. 2 , electro-catalysts play a crucial role in high-performance Li-S batteries by catalyzing the electrochemical reactions and enhancing the kinetics of electrochemical reactions [29]. The electro-catalytic surface is believed to facilitate the formation of crystalline Li2S2/Li2S and promote the corresponding reactions. Crystalline Li2S2/Li2S preferentially participates in sulfur reduction/oxidation reactions, thereby reducing interfacial resistance, improving sulfur utilization and activating sulfur redox reactions [30]. On the sulfur cathode, the catalytic effect can lower the reaction barrier between sulfur species and metal ions during electrochemical cycling, improve the kinetics of reactions and achieve higher conversion rates of LiPSs intermediates during charge–discharge processes [31]. Additionally, the introduction of electro-catalysts also can mitigate the LiPSs shuttling, enhance the electrochemical stability and prolong lifespan of the battery. Through the synergistic utilization of physical barriers provided by high surface area carriers and the catalytic activity of electro-catalysts, it is expected to simultaneously suppress the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and reduce lithium dendrite growth under reduced E/S conditions. The applied ways with the abilities of strong adsorption and excellent catalytic activity are both effective strategies for mitigating the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. However, the individual adsorption or catalytic effects have limited capability in improving the reaction kinetics to a certain degree. Therefore, it is urgent to develop catalysts with dual functionality including strong adsorption and catalysis for facilitating the transformation of LiPSs. Currently, many metal catalysts exhibit high adsorption and catalytic activity due to their unique coordination environments and tunable electronic structures. Various types of single-metal, bimetallic, and polymetallic catalysts have been studied and developed for further enhancing electrochemical performance of Li-S cells. Fig. 3 illustrates their respective advantages and disadvantages of single-metal, bimetallic and polymetallic materials. Compared to single-metal systems, polymetallic components often expose more abundant active sites, which are beneficial for the redox kinetics of LiPSs during the redox. Bimetallic systems can effectively exert a synergistic “adsorption-catalytic” effect, optimize electronic structure, enhance conductivity and reduce energy barriers, thus significantly enhancing catalytic activity through producing more diverse redox reactions. On one hand, nano-clusters with multiple atoms also demonstrate excellent performance due to high specific surface area, more active sites and so on. On the other hand, the coordination environment of transition metal electrocatalysts is considered a tunable factor for optimizing catalytic performance. However, a more complex metal composition is not always better to a certain extent. Compared to polymetallic materials, relatively simpler bimetallic materials usually possess some unique advantages. Firstly, bimetallic materials usually consist of two metal elements, which have relatively simple structures and usually exhibit greater stability and easier formation of the “adsorption-catalysis” interfaces when compared with single-metal or polymetallic materials, thus improving the reaction kinetics. Secondly, the synthesis of bimetallic materials is more convenient, and the control of metal element composition and structure may be comparatively easier than that of polymetallic materials. Moreover, the cost of bimetallic materials may be lower because they typically require fewer metal elements and are more amenable to mass production [32]. The morphologies of bimetallic materials are closely related to their catalytic performances. Morphologies refer to the structures, compositions and surface morphologies of bimetallic materials. These features determine the catalytic activities and selectivities of bimetallic materials. Firstly, the morphologies of bimetallic materials can affect surface characteristics such as specific surface area and lattice defects. Larger specific surface area and appropriate lattice defect can provide more active sites and enhance adsorption capacities, thereby promoting catalytic reactions. Secondly, the morphology of bimetallic materials can regulate the interaction between the metals. For example, if the two metals exhibit a highly dispersed nanoparticle morphology, it can increase the contact area and interaction between the metals, facilitating synergistic effects and thus improving catalytic activity. Additionally, bimetallic materials with different morphologies may have different surface structures, which can greatly affect the adsorption and diffusion rates of reactants on the catalyst surface, thereby significantly influencing the efficiency and selectivity of catalytic reactions. In conclusion, the morphology of bimetallic materials can have a significant impact on catalytic performance by regulating surface characteristics, metal interactions, and reactant adsorption and diffusion. The rational designs and controls of the morphologies of bimetallic materials can improve their catalytic activity, selectivity and stability. It is worth mentioning that the catalyst carrier also plays a crucial role in harnessing the advantages of catalysts. Firstly, the catalyst carrier should possess good electrical and ion conductivity to facilitate electron conduction and ion transport, thereby enhancing the performance and efficiency of the battery. Secondly, the catalyst carrier should have a large specific surface area to increase the number of active sites of the catalysts, resulting in improved reaction rates and enhanced electrochemical performance. Thirdly, the catalyst carrier also should exhibit good chemical stability to resist sulfur corrosion and catalyst deactivation, thereby prolonging the battery’s lifespan. Lastly, the catalyst carrier should possess sufficient mechanical strength to withstand the stress and deformation during battery cycling, ensuring the stability and activity of the catalysts. Many researchers utilize carbon materials with high specific surface area as the carrier for metal catalysts. For instance, the design and synthesis of porous carbon nanofibers with high active surface area and abundant active sites have been prepared and employed to load bimetallic compounds. Well-designed catalyst carrier also can provide a larger reactive surface area, increase the number of active sites and enable uniform dispersion of the catalysts, thereby exhibiting excellent catalytic performance. Bimetallic compound-carbon composite materials demonstrate high catalytic activity towards LiPSs, along with strong adsorption capability, effectively accelerating the kinetics of LiPSs conversion. Simultaneously, bimetallic catalysts and carriers also can potentially enhance the diffusion rate of lithium ions, suppress lithium dendrite formation and improve the stability and cycling lifespan of the battery. Therefore, by modifying the synthesis method, structure and combining form of bimetallic catalysts and supports, their adsorption and catalytic performance can be significantly improved, thereby enhancing the reaction rate and cycling stability of Li-S batteries. Given the rapid progresses in the researching field (Fig. 4 ), this review presents a comprehensive summarization of recent advancements in utilizing bimetallic materials to suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSs and accelerate the reaction kinetics in LSBs. As shown in Fig. 5 , this review also provides a summary and discussion of the application achievements of bimetallic materials in the cathode, separator and interlayer, encompassing bimetallic alloys, oxides, sulfides, phosphides, carbides, nitrides, hydroxides, selenides, MOFs and their composites. Furthermore, the paper introduces the challenges and future prospects faced by bimetallic materials in realizing the commercial application of high-performance LSBs. 2 Mechanisms of suppressing “shuttle effect” of LiPSs The “shuttle effect” of LiPSs is widely recognized as a significant barrier to the commercialization of LSBs. During the redox reaction involving “S8-LiPSs-Li2S,” elemental sulfur undergoes a phase transition from solid to liquid and back to solid within liquid electrolyte [33]. In this process, soluble LiPSs inevitably dissolve from the host and migrate due to the concentration difference, penetrating the separator and depositing onto the negative electrode. The results in the loss of active materials, particularly under conditions of high sulfur loading and long-term cycling, exacerbating the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Therefore, it is necessary to seek effective strategies and sulfur host materials to immobilize sulfur species. 2.1 Physical adsorption of LiPSs The mechanism of physical adsorption of LiPSs can be achieved through the interaction between the adsorbent and LiPSs. The adsorbent typically possesses a high surface area and porous structure, providing more adsorption sites. When the LiPSs molecules come into contact with the surface of adsorbent, they interact with the forces between them, resulting in their adsorptions onto the surface of the adsorbent. This physical adsorption mechanism can be achieved through some interactions such as van der Waals forces and electrostatic interactions [34]. Various carbon materials have been used as sulfur hosts to enhance conductivity and physically adsorb soluble LiPSs. Carbon materials usually possess excellent conductivity, high porosity, strong adsorption capacity and low cost. By constructing a conductive network with carbon materials, the poor conductivity of elemental sulfur can be compensated. More importantly, carbon materials exhibit a complex pore structure which can physically confine LiPSs, preventing their dissolution and diffusion and suppressing the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Additionally, the porous nature of carbon materials allows for uniform distribution of sulfur within the carbon matrix, increasing sulfur loading and providing abundant active sites. Some carbon materials also possess good mechanical strength to alleviate volume expansion during the charge–discharge process of LSBs. Currently, extensively studied carbon composites mainly include porous carbons, carbon nanotubes, graphenes, and carbon fiber composites and their composites 2.2 Chemical adsorption of LiPSs The weak interactions between carbon materials and LiPSs during the lithiation process can only be maintained for a short time, and the ability of physical adsorption based on van der Waals forces to restrict LiPSs is rather limited. Highly soluble LiPSs can still diffuse through the physical barrier. Therefore, some researchers also have considered the formation of chemical adsorption through reactions with functional groups on the surface to prevent the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Chemical adsorption, by forming strong chemical bonds, can effectively trap sulfur species within the region of cathode, significantly suppressing LiPSs diffusion, thus improving cycle stability and Coulombic efficiency. In simple terms, the key difference lies in the fact that “physical adsorption” relies on intermolecular forces, while “chemical adsorption” is based on the chemical bonding forces [35]. One feasible strategy is to immobilize LiPSs through surface Lewis acid-base interactions. Lithium atoms in LiPSs can effectively coordinate with sulfur, possessing additional lone pair electrons, making them soft Lewis bases. At the same time, the covalent interactions also exist between the highest occupied molecular orbital of Lewis bases and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital of Lewis acids, leading to effective charge transfer from Lewis bases to Lewis acids. Therefore, some researchers also add Lewis acidic materials to sulfur-based materials, forming acid-base complexes through strong Lewis acid-base interactions, effectively adsorbing intermediate products LiPSs and accelerating the reaction kinetics of sulfur species. Another strategy to suppress LiPSs shuttle is through polar-polar interactions. Polar molecules usually contain polar bonds due to differences in electronegativity between bonded atoms. The intermolecular forces between polar molecules, such as dipole–dipole or hydrogen bonding, are much stronger than the interactions between polar and nonpolar molecules [36]. For anchoring LiPSs, the chemical affinity in polar-polar interactions is more favorable. Polar materials usually also exhibit strong interactions with LiPSs due to their inherent polarity, contributing to enhanced electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Some transition metal compounds can not only adsorb LiPSs through polar metal-nonmetal chemical bonding, providing abundant active sites, but also catalyze the conversion between LiPSs and Li2S2/Li2S. Currently, researches focus on chemical adsorption include heteroatom-doped carbon, transition metal compounds and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which can offer rich chemical anchor sites for LiPSs, suppress the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs, accelerate reaction kinetics and provide improved stability, high reversibility, and long cycle life for Li-S batteries. 2.3 Adsorption-catalysis synergy of LiPSs For accelerating the electrochemical kinetics of sulfur reactions, some researchers have investigated various catalytic materials, such as different MOFs, transition metal elements and their compounds, which can catalyze the transformation of sulfur species after anchoring LiPSs [37,38]. However, the activity of a single adsorbent or catalyst is limited to a certain extent, making it difficult to achieve simultaneous adsorption and conversion of multiple LiPSs in a complex environment. Excessive adsorption strength can significantly increase the energy barrier for the transformation between soluble LiPSs, which is rather detrimental to the desorption and rapid conversion of LiPSs. Therefore, establishing a synergistic mechanism of “strong adsorption” and “fast conversion” for LiPSs is rather crucial for the application of high-performance Li-S batteries. Co-doping for different functional adsorbents and catalysts through engineering is an effective strategy to accelerate the internal kinetics of Li-S batteries. The adsorption-catalysis synergy can significantly enhance the adsorption and conversion capabilities of solid–liquid interface adsorption-catalytic sites for LiPSs [39]. Bimetallic materials usually have unique advantages in achieving this synergistic mechanism by forming more stable interfacial transitions. Polar bimetallic compounds usually possess abundant empty d orbitals and reactive sites, which are expected to form stronger chemical bonds with electron-rich LiPSs, effectively anchoring them. Moreover, the multi-metal components also can expose more active sites and high catalytic sites loaded on the conductive surface. The enriched adsorption-catalysis sites at the bimetallic interfaces can facilitate the rapid adsorption-catalytic conversion of LiPSs and regulate the redox kinetics between LiPSs and Li2S, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. In summary, these relative mechanisms play a role in suppressing the shuttle effect of LiPSs. By combining these mechanisms, it is expected to design modified materials with stable structures and excellent physical and chemical properties for application in modified cathodes, modified separators and self-supporting interlayers, effectively mitigating the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and achieving higher performance Li-S batteries. 3 Researching progress of bimetallic materials in high performance lithium-sulfur batteries To address the challenges in Li-S batteries, particularly the suppression of LiPSs shuttling, various methods have been proposed, including physical confinement, chemical adsorption and catalytic conversion. Composite materials have been utilized as sulfur hosts, and the introduction of carbon materials also is considered a promising approach to enhance the conductivity of active materials and sulfur utilization, as well as to mitigate the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs through physical confinement. Recent studies also have shown that the utilization of metal compound-loaded carbon materials with large specific surface areas can provide effective active sites, leading to dual physical and chemical adsorption interactions with LiPSs. With further researches, some researchers also have discovered that bimetallic compounds and their composites also possess excellent structural features and chemical properties, such as significant suppression of LiPSs shuttling and efficient catalytic conversion. Specifically, the following aspects have been considered. (1) The combination of bimetallic materials and carbon host materials can effectively enhance electronic conductivity and physically confine sulfur species within a certain space to accommodate huge volume changes during the cycling process of Li-S batteries while maintaining structural stability. (2) Bimetallic materials can exert effective polar adsorption on LiPSs combining some physical limitation, thus reducing the LiPSs shuttling for further enhancing the electrochemical performance of Li-S cell. (3) Highly tunable bimetallic materials can be endowed with additional functional characteristics for the final composite, such as synergistically enhanced catalytic capability. (4) Bimetallic materials can form rapid “adsorption-catalysis” interfaces for the conversion of LiPSs, effectively preventing the accumulation of LiPSs on the cathode surface during the charging process and significantly improving their utilizations. (5) By reasonably selecting bimetallic materials with strong polarity and lithium affinity, the diffusion rate of lithium ions can be effectively enhanced, suppressing the growth of lithium dendrites. Additionally, many researchers have proposed the feasibility of preparing bimetallic composite materials by combining bimetallic materials with other multi-functional materials. Ultimately, by fully utilizing the advantages of bimetallic structures and leveraging the synergistic effects of additional structural and chemical modifications, outstanding electrochemical performance and safety for the assembled Li-S cell can be achieved. Excellent structure designs greatly contribute to the improvement of bimetallic materials’ performance. Current researching efforts mainly focus on designing heterogeneous structures, defect structures and hollow porous carrier structures. Heterogeneous structure engineering enables the adjustment of the electronic structure of bimetallic compounds, facilitating enhanced interaction with LiPSs and suppressing their shuttle effect. Altering the electron distribution within the heterogeneous structure can lower the potential barrier, improving the kinetics of oxidation–reduction processes, which can include LiPSs phase transition and Li2S deposition/dissolution during charge/discharge. Defect engineering also can promote the formation of sulfur radicals, accelerating LiPSs conversion. Defect sites possess abundant localized electrons, serving as active centers for LiPSs adsorption. Specifically, oxygen defects can inhibit charge carrier recombination, lowering the energy barrier for interfacial charge transfer. Sulfur defects, based on sulfides, also exhibit excellent catalytic properties. Furthermore, the performance of nitride materials also can be optimized by designing nitrogen defects. More importantly, defect engineering effectively combines the advantages of bimetallic materials, facilitating synergistic adsorption-catalysis. For fully exploiting the benefits of bimetallic materials, the carrier choice is crucial. Various carbon materials, with their high surface area and porous structure, are employed as adsorbents or catalyst carriers, providing numerous active sites. Employing hollow enclosed structures (e.g., hollow eggshell structures, hollow nanocages and hollow microtubes) or porous semi-enclosed structures (e.g., porous carbon nanofibers and carbon nanoparticles) effectively restricts the spatial location and significantly promotes reactions of sulfur and LiPSs within the structures. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline materials composed of metal ions or clusters coordinated with organic ligands. MOFs usually possess open coordination metal sites, acting as soft Lewis acids, effectively coordinating with LiPSs through Lewis acid-base interactions. MOFs offer high adjustability and diversity, enabling efficient adsorption and catalytic performance through different metal and ligand combinations. Prussian blue analogs (PBAs) are porous coordination polymers with large frameworks, which can be used for sulfur storage similar to MOFs. Due to their remarkable structural advantages, extensive researches employ MOFs and PBAs as precursors for bimetallic material synthesis. In conclusion, structures with large specific surface areas can provide numerous active sites. Various structurally and functionally promising materials are being widely researched and applied for Li-S cell. 3.1 Preparation methods of bimetallic materials Currently, there are various methods available for synthesizing bimetallic materials. Each of these methods has its own unique advantages in producing bimetallic nanoparticles. Here, we have summarized some commonly used synthesis approaches with the hope of providing important references for future researches. 3.1.1 Solvent thermal method The solvent thermal method utilizes the dissolution and reaction of bimetallic precursors in a solvent, under appropriate conditions, to induce the aggregation and precipitation of metal ions, resulting in the formation of bimetallic nanoparticles. The solvent thermal method allows for high controllability over the morphology, particle size, composition and structure of bimetallic materials by adjusting parameters such as the solvent, reaction conditions, and precursor ratios. Bimetallic materials prepared by the solvent thermal method typically exhibit good uniformity. In a high-temperature and solvent environment, metal ions can diffuse and interact with each other, facilitating intermetallic alloying and thus yielding uniformly distributed bimetallic structures. The solvent thermal method can also be used to produce bimetallic materials with various metal combinations, allowing for the acquisition of materials with diverse and excellent properties by controlling the composition and proportion of the kinds of two metals. Furthermore, the solvent thermal method usually does not require expensive equipment or complex processing steps. The reaction conditions are relatively mild, making it suitable for industrial-scale production. It is worth noting that the solvent thermal method also presents some challenges in terms of solvent selection and treatment, optimization of reaction conditions, as well as subsequent material processing and characterization. Therefore, careful consideration and resolution of these issues are necessary in practical applications to ensure the quality and performance of bimetallic materials. 3.1.2 Chemical vapor deposition method Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) is a method used to generate bimetallic nanoparticles through metal evaporation and gas-phase reactions under high temperature conditions. These nanoparticles are then deposited onto a substrate, creating a bilayer or alloy structure on its surface. CVD allows for the production of bimetallic materials with complex heterostructures and controlled interfaces. By adjusting the material composition and deposition sequence, bimetallic materials with specific structures and functionalities, such as core–shell, multilayer structures and so on, can be synthesized. CVD can be conducted in a high-temperature atmosphere, enabling direct deposition of materials in the solid-state. The way eliminates impurity introduction and results in high-purity bimetallic materials. Moreover, precise and sharp bimetallic interfaces can be achieved through the control of gas flow in CVD. Some researchers also fabricate bimetallic nanoparticles or thin films with specific nanoscale dimensions by controlling parameters such as deposition time, deposition rate and deposition temperature. Compared to other fabrication methods, CVD is suitable for the production of large-area bimetallic materials and offers some advantages in terms of continuity. It allows for the continuous growth of large-area bimetallic films. However, it is important to note that CVD requires high process temperatures, precise gas flow control and sophisticated equipment. Additionally, the choice and pre-treatment of substrates also affect the final properties of bimetallic materials. 3.1.3 Melt diffusion method The melt diffusion method enables the formation of alloy-structured nanoparticles from two metals at suitable temperatures and ratios. By subjecting powders or thin sheets of two different metals to high-temperature heat treatment, bimetallic nanoparticles can be formed through mutual diffusion. During the melting process, the molten metal can evenly mix the two metals through diffusion, providing bimetallic materials with good interface bonding strength and homogeneity. The melt diffusion method is applicable to various combinations of metals, allowing for the preparation of bimetallic materials with different properties and applications by reasonably selecting different metal combinations or adding other elements. The composition of bimetallic materials can be controlled by adjusting the proportions and amounts of the raw metal materials. Additionally, by controlling parameters such as heating time and temperature, thickness and morphology of bimetallic materials also can be controlled. The melt diffusion method has relatively low costs. And it does not require complex equipment or precise control, making it an economically effective choice for preparing bimetallic materials. However, the melt diffusion method also faces certain challenges, such as material handling and control in high-temperature environments as well as the speed and depth of metal diffusion. 3.1.4 Calcination method The calcination method primarily involves the high-temperature treatment of materials to enhance the particle bonding, increase grain size, thereby altering the properties and structure of the material. In the preparation of bimetallic materials, the calcination method can be employed as a subsequent processing step to adjust and optimize the properties of the bimetallic precursor materials. Firstly, high-temperature calcination promotes mutual diffusion and alloying reactions between the two metals, further enhancing the uniformity and performance of the bimetallic material. Secondly, the elevated temperature during calcination facilitates grain growth and adjustment of grain boundaries, thereby improving the crystalline properties and lattice matching of the bimetallic material. Additionally, the surface diffusion and recombination processes at high temperatures during calcination process can alter the specific surface area of the bimetallic material, consequently affecting its adsorption properties and catalytic activity. 3.1.5 Electrospinning method Electrospinning is a relatively simple and practical method that can be carried out in a conventional laboratory without the need for complex equipment or conditions. The technique allows for the rapid preparation of nanomaterials, with the process typically taking only a few minutes to a few hours. The resulting bimetallic materials are often in the form of nanofibers, which exhibit high surface area and porous structures, being beneficial for various applications and performance enhancement. By using electrospinning way, the two metals are intertwined or coated together, resulting in a closely bonded interface which can provide high strength and stability. Therefore, bimetallic materials prepared through electrospinning way usually exhibit excellent interfacial bonding strength. The size, morphology and distribution of the nanomaterials can be precisely controlled through adjustments to the electrospinning parameters, such as solution concentration, spinning voltage and spinning distance. For instance, different proportions of bimetallic nanofibers or nanoparticles can be obtained by varying the concentration ratio of the two metals in the mixed solution. By altering the fiber or particle formation process, bimetallic materials with different shapes (e.g., fibers, membranes, particles) and structures (e.g., core–shell structures, alternating arrangements or other formation) can be synthesized. Furthermore, electrospinning is a relatively simple and scalable technique. It can be easily implemented without the need for complex equipment and conditions, making it suitable for large-scale preparation. However, it is important to have a thorough understanding of the dissolution characteristics, spinnability and other properties of different metals when using electrospinning to prepare bimetallic materials. This is necessary to ensure the stability of the synthesis process and the quality of the bimetallic nanofibers. Additionally, although electrospinning offers many advantages, it is important to address the challenges related to process control and uniformity which may arise during nanoscale fabrication. 3.1.6 Template method Template method can be used to synthesize bimetallic nanoparticles by depositing two different metals sequentially into the template pores using methods such as deposition, electrochemistry or other techniques, and then removing the template. Alternatively, bimetallic materials with uniformly distributed metal atoms also can be achieved by substituting the original metal nodes in MOFs with external metal atoms. By selecting different types of template structures, such as MOFs, nanoporous arrays or porous materials, the template method allows for the preparation of bimetallic materials with different structural characteristics and properties, enabling control over pore sizes, shapes, and distributions to meet various application requirements. Due to the formation of bimetallic materials on the template surface, the template method can control the interfacial properties of the bimetallic materials, enabling specific applications such as catalysis, electron transfer, and surface enhancement through the utilization of interfacial effects. More importantly, the template method is applicable to a wide range of metal systems, allowing for the fabrication of bimetallic materials with different metal combinations, demonstrating high scalability and versatility. Furthermore, the template method is scalable and also can be applied at different scales, ranging from nanoscale to macroscopic, to fulfill diverse application needs. It is worth noting that the template method also has some limitations, such as the difficulty in selecting and preparing templates, the removal of templates, and the influence of template materials on the final material performance. Therefore, careful consideration of these factors, along with optimization and improvement, is necessary when employing the template method for the synthesis of bimetallic materials. When some researchers are selecting methods for the preparation of bimetallic materials, various factors such as the compositions, morphologies, and controlled sizes of the nanoparticles, as well as the feasibility and economic considerations of the synthesis methods, still need to be taken into account. Furthermore, optimizing experimental conditions and adjusting reaction parameters also have significant impacts on the synthesis outcomes. Therefore, the selection of specific methods should be carefully weighed and optimized based on the actual requirements and research objectives. 3.2 Modified cathodes The electrode can be served as the primary source of energy in batteries, and modifying the electrode is one of the most effective approaches to enhance battery performance. For the cathode electrode of LSBs, the supply and storage of energy mainly involve multiple processes of conversion between elemental sulfur and LiPSs. Over the past few decades, extensive researches have been conducted on sulfur hosts to ensure smooth electron transfer between conductors and active materials. Various carbon materials have been employed to modify the cathode electrode. However, relying solely on physical constraints is insufficient to suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSs during long-term cycling. Due to the weak van der Waals forces between nonpolar carbon and polar LiPSs, rapid capacity decay is also inevitable. To overcome the limitations of physical adsorption, much attention has shifted towards polar materials, including metal oxides [40], metal selenides [41], metal phosphides [42], metal sulfides [43], MXenes [44] and MOFs [45], as they exhibit strong chemical interactions with sulfur species. Among these materials, bimetallic compounds and their modified materials combined with sulfur offers excellent conductivity, chemical adsorption and catalytic performance, effectively improving the rate capability and long-term cycling of LSBs. These bimetallic modified materials primarily include bimetallic alloy, sulfides, oxides, phosphides, carbides, nitrides, hydroxides, selenides and MOF-derived materials. 3.2.1 Bimetallic alloys Transition metal-based alloys (TMAs) are considered promising sulfur-active materials due to high electrochemical conductivity and electrocatalytic activity. Bimetallic alloys can form a favorable interface structure with sulfides, improving interface stability and bonding strength. The phenomenon can prevent sulfide dissolution and diffusion, reducing sulfide loss and extending the battery’s cycle life. Bimetallic alloys exhibit good electrocatalytic activity and stable catalytic surfaces, promoting the reaction kinetics of sulfides and reducing the occurrence of polarization, thereby enhancing the cycle stability and energy density of the battery. Meanwhile, bimetallic alloys have advantages in catalysis, polarization inhibition, interface stability, and ion conductivity in LSBs. These advantages contribute to improving the energy density, cycle life and power performance of the battery, promoting the development and application of LSBs. Transition metal-based alloys catalysts have attracted widespread attention due to their high selectivity, activity and stability. Among them, CoFe alloy has been demonstrated as an excellent electrocatalyst. When combining with carbon materials as a direct electrocatalyst, it can effectively anchor and catalyze LiPSs, suppressing LiPSs shuttle and accelerating electrochemical reaction kinetics. For example, Cai et al. [46] combined the thermal decomposition components of MF resin with bimetallic Fe-Co catalyst to successfully prepare the N-doped hierarchical porous carbon-carbon nanotube hybrids (N-HPC-CNT) on the HPC (Fig. 6 C). The prepared N-HPC-CNT hybrids consisted of mesopores and macropores. They not only provided sufficient pore volume for sulfur, but also effectively adsorbed soluble LiPSs. In the hybrid structure, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) enhanced the conductivity and can be acted as physical barriers, blocking some of the larger pores on HPC, finally reducing the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. The C3N4, known for its high pyridinic N content, was expected to provide more active sites for anchoring LiPSs. Li et al. [47] constructed an efficient Fe/Co-C3N4/C electrocatalyst with a large surface area and high conductivity through a simple sol-gel and high-temperature calcination method. The polar Fe/Co-C3N4/C with its multi-level porous structure facilitated the efficient catalytic conversion of LiPSs to Li2S2/Li2S, promoting electrochemical kinetics and thus improving the cycling stability and rate performance of the assembled battery using the electrode. The initial specific capacity of a lithium-sulfur battery with Fe/Co-C3N4/C/S as the cathode and a sulfur loading amount of 1.8 mg cm−2 was 949 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C. After 135 cycles, the reversible specific capacity remained at 749 mA h g−1 with a cycling decay rate of 0.156%. Using carbon materials to encapsulate alloys is a beneficial strategy. These enclosed shells confine LiPSs within a narrow space, allowing them to react with the internal alloy catalyst. This strategy effectively curbs the shuttling of LiPSs and enhances reaction kinetics. Gao et al. [48] designed and prepared an independent three-dimensional (3D) porous carbon film embedded with the CoFe bimetallic nanoparticles through a simple pyrolysis process. The CoFe bimetallic nanoparticles were encapsulated by a graphite shell, forming a CoFe@C yolk-shell structure. These CoFe bimetallic nanoparticles can be served as effective catalysts for the conversion of soluble LiPSs. The in-situ growth of the graphite shell around the CoFe bimetallic nanoparticles can be acted as a nanoreactor which can effectively restrict and absorb the LiPSs. The interaction between Co and Fe also could be effectively regulated by adjusting the alloy’s electronic structure to tune the catalytic activity. Good conductivity was crucial for improving low-temperature performance. The independent 3D porous carbon film composed of carbon nanofibers (CNFs) can be served as a framework, providing electron transfer channels, alleviating the large volume changes during charging and discharging, and preventing Li2S accumulation. Therefore, the designed CoFe@C@CNFs host exhibited advantages of efficient adsorption, confinement and conversion of LiPSs along with high conductivity and specific surface area. The prepared hierarchical host displayed a synergistic effect, enhancing the overall performance of low-temperature LSBs and ensuring more complete redox processes, thereby achieving higher sulfur utilization. The CoFe@C@CNF cathode, when designed properly, exhibited excellent rate capability (828 mA h g−1 at 10 C) and low decay rate (0.053% per cycle over 300 cycles). Enhanced capacity (836 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C) and cycling stability (94.5% capacity retention after 100 cycles) could be achieved at 20 C. The research will provide a feasible approach for developing high-rate and long-life LSBs for low-temperature applications. At the same time, Cao et al. [49] synthesized nitrogen-doped carbon-coated CoFe alloy nanoparticles (E-CoFeCN@C) (Fig. 6B). The obtained E-CoFeCN@C provided abundant surface area and sufficient space, enabling efficient utilization of sulfur and LiPSs. The N-doped carbon shell on the surface of E-CoFeCN@C and the N-doped carbon encapsulation of CoFe alloy nanoparticles synergistically contributed to the overall performance. The uniform distribution of catalytic sites in the Co-Fe alloy greatly improved the kinetics of the redox reactions in LSBs and suppressed the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs, while the confinement provided by the intact carbon shell helped anchor S and LiPSs within the structured materials. The prepared E-CoFeCN@C as sulfur host exhibited high specific capacity and excellent cycling stability as the cathode of LSBs. Meanwhile, Shi et al. [50] designed and prepared a CoFe alloy embedded in a mesoporous carbon sphere structure (CoFe-MCS) as a high-performance sulfur host using extrusion-based 3D printing technology. The CoFe bimetallic alloy interacted moderately with LiPSs and can be served as an efficient electrocatalyst for the regulation of LiPSs, greatly suppressing their shuttle effect. The prepared CoFe-MCS exhibited superior electrocatalytic activity in the bidirectional redox process when compared to related monometallic counterparts (such as Fe-MCS). The 3D-printed S@CoFe-MCS electrode allowed for adjustable sulfur loading and demonstrated excellent electrochemical performance. The prepared S@CoFe-MCS cathode demonstrated excellent rate performance with a sulfur loading of 4.0 mg cm−2, achieving an advanced areal capacity of 6.0 mA h cm−2 at a sulfur loading of 7.7 mg cm−2. These studies explore the non-precious metal alloy electrocatalysts in the cathode for achieving bidirectional lithium polysulfide conversion, holding great potential for the commercialization of Li-S batteries. The synergistic effect of NiCo often exhibits enhanced catalytic performance. When nickel (Ni) and cobalt (Co) coexist in a eutectic manner, alloyed nanoparticles can form unique lattice structures, offering heightened catalytic activity and stability. The NiCo alloy nanoparticles possess a high surface area and abundant active sites, thereby providing an increased number of adsorption sites and enhancing their affinity towards reactants. Furthermore, the NiCo alloy nanoparticles also can offer additional conduits for electrical conduction, expediting electron transfer and consequently elevating the rate of catalytic reactions. Li et al. [51] designed and developed the flower-shaped microsphere-like reduced graphene oxide (rGO) embedded with finely dispersed Ni2Co alloy nanoparticles (Ni2Co@rGO) as the cathode material for LSBs (Fig. 6D). The obtained unique structure provided high porosity and a large surface area, exposing active interfaces. Furthermore, the densely packed rGO components exhibited good long-range conductivity, while the gaps between folded nanosheets also provided fast channels for ion transport. The Ni2Co alloy nanoparticles possessed excellent sulfur adsorption performance and electrocatalytic activity, effectively stabilizing and accelerating sulfur reactions. In addition, the prepared Ni2Co@rGO matrix demonstrated good lithiophilicity, inhibiting dendrite growth and enabling uniform lithium deposition and reversible lithium insertion/extraction. The constructed S-Ni2Co@rGO cathode exhibited excellent cycling performance, and a full cell configuration combining the S-Ni2Co@rGO cathode and the Li-Ni2Co@rGO anode achieved stable cycling with high sulfur loading. Over a span of 500 cycles, the minimum capacity decay per cycle was 0.034%, demonstrating a high-rate capability of up to 5 C. Designing microstructural features with a large specific surface area can generally effectively increase the number of exposed active sites. The utilization of polyhedral-modified carbon nanotubes, derived from the pyrolysis of bimetallic MOFs precursors, not only exhibits a high porosity but also exposes active sites for the sulfur-oxygen reduction reaction. Moreover, the interconnected carbon network provides excellent conductivity. Li et al. [52] designed and prepared the composite conductive scaffold (CoNi-NC/CNTs) by hybridizing the CoNi-N-doped porous carbon polyhedra (CoNi-NC) with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) as the electrode material for the sulfur electrode. The thermal decomposition of the bimetallic MOFs precursor formed an intermediate layer with abundant N-doping, Co, Ni-N-C heterostructures and ultra-fine bimetallic particles, providing numerous electrocatalytic and adsorption sites, thus facilitating the conversion of Li2S6 to Li2S4 and the subsequent Li2S4 to Li2S2 processes. Due to these structural advantages, the composite material Co0.75Ni0.25-NC/CNTs can be acted as a reliable barrier, efficiently trapping LiPSs, reducing the shuttle effect of LiPSs and improving battery performance. The 3D network structure of PNCFs with high specific surface area also facilitated the exposure of more active sites for electron/ion transport. Due to these favorable characteristics, the assembled Li-S cell assembled with this cathode exhibited excellent electrochemical performance with an initial discharge capacity of 1320.8 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C. He et al. [53] successfully prepared a three-dimensional independent multifunctional bimetallic porous N-doped carbon fiber system (CoNi@PNCFs) (Fig. 6A). The experimental results showed that the N-doped carbon layer coated with CoNi and Co/Ni-N active sites exhibited strong adsorption capability for soluble Li2S and effectively promoted its conversion to insoluble Li2S. In addition, when used as a lithium metal anode, the 3D framework of the porous carbon fiber matrix could provide sufficient buffer space to accommodate and release Li during the plating/stripping process. The flexible 3D carbon network with uniformly distributed N-C sites facilitated the uniform growth of Li. Furthermore, the synergistic effect of bimetallic transition metal nanoparticles often could enhance the catalytic performance. Therefore, using the CoNi@PNCFs as the sulfur and lithium host in assembly for a LSBs resulted in a higher initial reversible specific capacity and demonstrated stable long-term cycling performance. The assembled Li-S battery, equipped with the S/CoNi@PNCFs as the cell cathode and Li/CoNi@PNCFs as the anode, demonstrated a high reversible specific capacity of 785 mA h g−1 and long cycling performance at 5 C (with a capacity decay rate of 0.016% after 1500 cycles). Copper (Cu) can form chemical bonds with sulfur, preventing the dissolution of LiPSs during cycling. Molybdenum (Mo) is currently one of the most popular transition metals, known for its controllable structure and variable valences, making it an efficient catalyst for LiPSs. Cheng et al. [54] proposed the incorporation of Cu-Mo bimetallic nanoparticles into suspended N-doped porous carbon nanofibers (Cu-Mo@NPCN) and utilized the anion exchange of cationic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) to prepare nanoscale Cu-Mo bimetallic particles with highly efficient catalytic sites and high sulfur loading capability. The balanced valence states of Cu and Mo in the porous Cu-Mo@NPCN, along with their coordination ability towards LiPSs, can effectively provide suitable adsorption capacity and enhance catalytic activity, thereby achieving efficient LiPSs capture and rapid conversion. Additionally, the entangled conductive network can offer a high surface area with abundant catalytically active sites, while the porous framework of electrospun carbon nanofibers also can enable uniform sulfur distribution and realize the effective sulfur confinement. Consequently, the standalone Cu-Mo@NPCN/S cathode can obtain high volumetric/gravimetric capacity and long cycling life, even under high sulfur loading and high flow rate conditions. Furthermore, some other metal alloy nanoparticles such as Pd3Co, PtNi and CoSn have been prepared and applied in LSBs due to their excellent theoretical specific capacity, convenient preparation methods, and low cost. Yom et al. [55] synthesized the Pd3Co nanoparticles using modified polyol method and prepared the sulfur electrode containing these nanoparticles, serving as an efficient cathode electrode for LSBs with enhanced redox reaction kinetics. The assembled batteries with Pd3Co nanoparticles exhibited outstanding cycling performance and high capacity retention at high current densities. The presence of Pd3Co nanoparticles played a crucial role in suppressing the dissolution of high-order LiPSs during discharge process and converting them into lower-order species. Additionally, the presence of Pd3Co nanoparticles increased the conductivity of the naturally insulating sulfur electrode. The final results indicated that the polarization of Pd3Co-based batteries was lower when compared to bare sulfur-based batteries. Moreover, the assembled Pd3Co-based batteries showed significantly higher specific capacity, excellent capacity retention and high Coulombic efficiency when compared to bare sulfur-based batteries. At the same time, the Pt and Ni have been proven to have electrocatalytic effects on the conversion reaction of LiPSs. Liu et al. [56] designed and prepared a hollow porous carbon-coated Pt@Ni core-shell bimetallic catalyst as an efficient sulfur host, which effectively prevented the physical/chemical migration of LiPSs and provided efficient ions/electron pathways. The formed carbon shell protected the catalyst from loss and electrolyte corrosion, acting as a confined nanoreactor. The obtained Pt@Ni core-shell catalyst with a patchy nickel shell suppressed the shuttle of LiPSs by forming strong chemical bonds with them. More importantly, the prepared Pt@Ni core-shell bimetallic catalyst exhibited superior electrocatalytic performance when compared to pure Pt or pure Ni. The dual-function electrocatalysis of Pt@Ni accelerated the transformation of insoluble products into soluble LiPSs, greatly reducing the energy barrier between Li2S/Li2S2 and the catalyst. The Pt@Ni bimetallic catalyst accelerated the conversion of deposited Li2S/Li2S2 into soluble LiPSs and exhibited strong adsorption capability towards soluble LiPSs, thereby preventing their shuttle effects. The PtNi@C catalyst, with a reduced band-gap, not only improved the catalytic activity for the conversion of insoluble Li2S2/Li2S, but also exhibited significant long-term cycling stability in terms of adsorption sites and high conductivity, thereby enhancing the capture and conversion efficiency of LiPSs. Tin-based and cobalt-based carbon host materials usually possess excellent chemical adsorption and electrocatalytic activity towards LiPSs. Qiao et al. [57] prepared a porous Co x Sn y alloy-modified hollow N-doped carbon composite material (E-Co x Sn y /NC) as a sulfur host. The introduction of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and the thermal decomposition of polydopamine (PDA) induced the formation of the Co x Sn y alloy at high temperatures. The novel metal-N-carbon-based composite material exhibited strong chemical adsorption and electrocatalytic conversion activity towards LiPSs, accelerating the kinetics of redox reactions and minimizing the loss of LiPSs. The electrocatalytic effect of the prepared Co x Sn y alloy effectively promoted the kinetics of redox reactions. Based on the rapid electrocatalytic conversion activity of LiPSs, strong chemical adsorption and the novel hollow carbon structure, the prepared E-Co x Sn y @NC/S electrode demonstrated high specific capacity and excellent long-term cycling stability. In summary, bimetallic alloys can offer numerous electrocatalytic and adsorption sites. The interaction between the two metals can effectively modulate the catalytic activity by adjusting the alloy’s electronic structure. The synergistic effects of bimetallic alloys generally lead to enhanced catalytic performance. Furthermore, bimetallic alloys possess high conductivity, which can increase the discharge capacity and energy density of batteries. Bimetallic alloys can reduce polarization and overpotential effects, thereby improving the stability and safety of LSBs. However, there are still obstacles to overcome in the preparation of bimetallic alloys, such as significant differences in crystalline structure and thermal expansion coefficients between different metals, which may result in internal stress and deformation during the fabrication process. Furthermore, diffusion between the two metals may occur, leading to the formation of heterogeneous phases that can affect the mechanical properties and chemical stability of the alloy. Therefore, this paper proposes some suggestions for the improvement of bimetallic alloys in future researches. (1) Optimizing the composition of bimetallic alloys: By adjusting the composition and ratio of the bimetallic alloys, the performance of LSBs can be improved, enhancing the cycle life. (2) Modifying the surface properties of bimetallic alloys: By altering the surface properties such as hydrophobicity and catalytic characteristics, the reactivity between metals and sulfur can be reduced, thereby enhancing the stability and safety of batteries. (3) Exploring novel bimetallic alloys: Research and develop new types of bimetallic alloys that can provide better conductivity and electrochemical performance, further improving the performance of lithium-sulfur batteries. (4) Combining with other materials to enhance battery performance: Integrating bimetallic alloys with other materials such as conductive polymers and carbon-based materials can improve the conductivity and energy storage capacity of lithium-sulfur batteries. Table S1 presents detailed information on LSBs employing bimetallic alloy electrodes, providing some guidances for further researches on the application of bimetallic alloys in high-performance LSBs. 3.2.2 Bimetallic oxides Polar metal oxides are typically characterized by their structural stability, high specific surface area and strong metal-oxygen bonds, which endow them with robust adsorption capabilities. On the other hand, transition metal compounds (such as CoO [58], TiO2 [59], ZnO [60], NiO [61], MoO2 [62], MnO [63]) exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activity. As a result, certain bimetallic oxides, benefiting from their synergistic effects, demonstrate outstanding potential in enhancing the electrochemical performance of LSBs. Among these, NiCo2O4 stands out as a mixed-valence oxide with a spinel structure, where nickel ions occupy octahedral positions while cobalt ions are distributed among octahedral and tetrahedral sites. The polar nature of NiCo2O4 enables effective immobilization of LiPSs through the synergistic interaction among its surface metal or oxygen ions and S x 2− and Li+, thereby providing excellent electrocatalytic activity. Additionally, the coexistence of redox couples, Co3+/Co2+ and Ni3+/Ni2+, within the structure of NiCo2O4 spinel contributes to its remarkable electronic conductivity, effectively surpassing that of individual nickel and cobalt oxides by several orders of magnitude. These distinctive characteristics make NiCo2O4 as a promising sulfur-based material with potential to effectively enhance the performance of LSBs. One-dimensional nanomaterials exhibit a relatively large specific surface area, enabling the provision of a greater number of active sites. Additionally, their elongated and slender structure contributes to their high strengths and flexibilities, thereby demonstrating excellent mechanical properties. Liu et al. [64] prepared 1D NiCo2O4 nanofibers and utilized them as the carbon-free hosts for high-content sulfur. The prepared 1D nanostructure offered a favorable conductive networks and ion diffusion pathways for the dissolution-deposition process of the sulfur cathode. Simultaneously, while meeting the requirements for increasing weight capacity and volume capacity, the 1D NiCo2O4 nanofibers provided sufficient active sites for catalytic conversion of polar intermediate LiPSs. Two-dimensional nanosheets have a thickness of only a single atomic layer or a few atomic layers. As a result, they possess an extremely high specific surface area, which enables the provision of a greater number of active surfaces and facilitates catalytic reactions and adsorption. Due to these advantages, the obtained S/NiCo2O4 composite material exhibited a high specific capacity of 1125 mA h g−1 at a rate of 0.1 C, and maintains a low capacity decay rate of 0.039% per cycle after more than 1500 cycles at a rate of 1 C. Moreover, the planar structure of two-dimensional nanomaterials allows for convenient assembly with other nanomaterials, forming composite materials. Iqbal et al. [65] synthesized hollow microtubes composed of NiCo2O4 nanosheets. The hollow structure of the internal cavity also can provide structural stability by accommodating huge volume expansion during battery cycling. While the external NiCo2O4 nanosheets not only facilitate abundant sulfur encapsulation, but also offer a relatively large functional surface for the strong chemical binding of LiPSs. The prepared material possesses low charge transfer resistance, strong chemical interactions between Ni/Co cations and LiPSs, a hollow cavity with structural integrity and ultra-thin nanosheet-like structures on the surface of NiCo2O4 microtubes, which physically constrain and chemically anchor the LiPSs, preventing their dissolution in the applied organic electrolytes. [70] employed a synergistic defect and structural engineering strategy to design highly disordered Ni-Co oxide double-shell microspheres (NCO-HS) through one-pot synthesis and heat treatment (Fig. 7B). Mn-based oxides effectively buffered the huge volume changes of Sn-based oxides, resulting in stable electrochemical performance. Mn-Sn bimetallic oxides have a good mesoporous structure and strong chemical adsorption properties for LiPSs, limiting the dissolution of LiPSs in the liquid electrolyte. Therefore, some mesoporous Mn-Sn bimetallic oxide nano-cubes currently have great potential as sulfur-based cathode materials for LiPSs. In summary, bimetallic oxides exhibit high reactivity, promoting chemical reactions between lithium ions and sulfur, which helps improve the reversible capacity and charge/discharge efficiency of batteries. Additionally, bimetallic oxides typically possess good ionic conductivity, facilitating the conversion and fast diffusion of Li+ in the cathode material, thereby enhancing the energy density and cycling performance of batteries. These oxides demonstrate favorable electrochemical stability during the charging and discharging processes, good resisting oxidation and reduction reactions within the electrode materials which can help reduce capacity decay and extend the battery’s cycle life. Furthermore, bimetallic oxides offer adjustability and diversity, allowing researchers to optimize battery performance by adjusting the material’s composition, structure and morphology. This provides more design space to meet the performance requirements of different application scenarios. However, bimetallic oxides used as cathode materials for LSBs also have some drawbacks. For example, these oxides often possess lower electrical conductivity, limiting the electronic conduction capability within the cathode materials, which may result in lower power density and decrease high-rate charge/discharge performance of the battery. Currently, some researchers commonly adopt some measures to enhance the overall conductivity of bimetallic oxides by incorporating highly conductive materials into them. The common conductive additives mainly include carbon materials (such as graphene and conductive carbon black) and conductive polymers (such as polypyrrole and polyaniline). These additives can form connected networks to enhance electron conduction. Moreover, adjusting the structure of bimetallic oxides such as particle size and crystal structure can also improve their conductivity. Smaller particle size can increase the material’s specific surface area, thereby increasing the number of electron conduction pathways. Optimizing crystal structure decreases the resistance to electron transport, thus enhancing electronic conductivity of the obtained materials. It is worth noting that high-temperature sintering treatment can effectively improve the crystalline quality and interfacial conductivity of bimetallic oxides. High-temperature sintering enables tighter bonding between material particles, enhancing the continuity of electron conduction. The significant difference in intermediate electronegativity between transition metal sulfides and LiPSs facilitates the adsorption of more LiPSs. In recent years, transition metal monosulfides such as MoS2 [77], Sb2S3 [78], Co9S8 [79], WS2 [80] and MnS [81] have gained widespread attention due to their unique metallic conductivity. These sulfides exhibit strong adsorption capacity for soluble LiPSs, and their superior conductivity also can effectively promote the redox kinetics of LiPSs. The electrical conductivity of bimetallic sulfide NiCo2S4 is superior to that of single-metal sulfides due to having more active sites and superior electrochemical properties. The hollow nanostructure is advantageous for increasing the loading of sulfur as well as providing physical confinement for LiPSs, which effectively weakens the shuttle effect and accelerates the conversion efficiency of LiPSs. [82] successfully synthesized hollow porous spinel-type bimetallic sulfide NiCo2S4 derived from prussian blue analogs, where the designed nanocubic structure was favorable for sulfur incorporation (Fig. 9 A). In comparison to other metal compounds, metal sulfides possess advantages such as high energy density, low cost and no pollution. Additionally, metal sulfides can enhance electronic conductivity, and their significant differences in electron affinity with LiPSs help in adsorbing more LiPSs. However, when used as positive electrode materials for lithium-sulfur batteries, the cycling stability and rate performance of metal sulfides are unsatisfactory. Some researchers generally alleviate these issues by controlling the nanostructure of metal sulfides and introducing conductive additives. By controlling the nanostructure of metal sulfides, the surface area and accessibility can be increased, promoting the diffusion and reaction rate of lithium ions in the electrode. The design of nanostructures can mitigate volume expansion and the formation of current collector membranes, improving the cycling stability of the electrode. By introducing conductive additives such as carbon nanotubes, conductive polymers, or conductive agents, the conductivity of metal sulfides can be enhanced, facilitating the transfer of electrons and ions, reducing the polarization effect of the electrode and improving the cycling stability of the battery. For bimetallic sulfides, many researchers mainly focus on designing nanostructures and heterogeneous structures. Constructing some nanostructures with a large specific surface area, such as hollow porous structures, nanocube structures, hollow nano-prism structures and yolk-shell hollow sphere structures, effectively increases active sites. This is advantageous for the immobilization and adsorption of LiPSs. Constructing heterogeneous structures of bimetallic sulfides with abundant phase boundaries and heterointerfaces can accelerate electrochemical kinetics, and the synergistic effects among different metal sulfide phases also can help stabilize the structural integrity of active materials during cycling. Additionally, TMSs compositing carbon materials are also an important approach, where TMSs can be served as polar materials to immobilize LiPSs, while the carbon framework can improve conductivity and alleviate huge volume expansion issues during charging and discharging processes. Cobalt phosphide (CoP) exhibits higher electrochemical activity for LiPSs conversion compared to cobalt oxide (Co3O4), and bimetallic phosphides show lower electron transfer resistance and higher catalytic activity than that of monometallic phosphides. The addition of other metals can effectively modulate the three-dimensional electronic structure, thereby improving the kinetics and electrocatalytic performance. Nickel (Ni) doping has a positive effect on the electronic properties of CoP, as the outermost orbitals of Ni modify the electronic states near the Fermi level of Co, resulting in a synergistic effect between Ni and Co which effectively promotes redox kinetics. The coupling of Ni and Co in bimetallic phosphides facilitates the modulation of the electronic states, leading to fewer filled antibonding states and more effective d-p orbital hybridization, enabling better combination with soluble Li2S and reducing the energy barrier for Li2S reduction/oxidation. For example, Zhou et al. [93] reported a bimetallic coupling-induced strategy, constructing a NiCoP-anchored N,P co-doped porous carbon(NPPC) framework through laser-induced micro-explosion to modulate the electronic state of the phosphide material for enhancing reaction kinetics and suppressed lithium dendrite growth (Fig. 10 A). The bimetallic coupling effect in the NiCoP-anchored N, P co-doped porous carbon (NiCoP-NPPC) hybrid enhanced the distribution of electronic states and uniformly adjusted the Li+ flux and potential barriers. These obtained results not only improved the conversion kinetics of polysulfides and increased sulfur utilization, but also effectively inhibited lithium dendrite growth. Due to the enhanced conductivity, abundant cation defects and exposed active sites, the prepared NiCoP-NPPC hybrid material exhibited strong chemical adsorption capability and excellent electrocatalytic activity. Moreover, based on the S@NiCoP-NPPC cathode and Li@NiCoP-NPPC anode, the full cell demonstrated excellent electrochemical performance.
