Therefore, the Li-S full cell assembled based on the prepared NiCoP-NPPC exhibited significantly improved capacity (1150 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C) and cycle stability (84.3% capacity retention after 1000 cycles). Furthermore, they also can even operate at high sulfur loading (6.9 mg cm−2) and low electrolyte utilization (5.2 µL mg−1), achieving a high areal capacity of 6.8 mA h cm−2 at 0.5 C. In addition, Zhang et al. [94] designed and prepared a bimetallic nickel cobalt phosphide with loaded reduced graphene oxide (NiCo2P X /rGO) as a bifunctional catalyst through various solvent-thermal methods (Fig. 10B). This composite material, which exhibited a yolk-shell structure with uniform dispersion, combined the advantages of NiCo2P X and rGO, promoting the kinetic efficiency of redox reactions and accelerating the decomposition of the final product (Li2S) during the charging process. The porous yolk-shell structure synthesized by anion exchange exposed more catalytic sites for large-scale cross-interactions. More importantly, the synergistic effect between the components of NiCo2P X /rGO accelerated the electron transfer and facilitated dynamic processes. Based on its unique functionalities and structures, the prepared NiCo2P X /rGO sulfur cathode exhibited a high capacity of 1238.7 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C and maintained a stable discharge capacity of 561.1 mA h g−1 after 400 cycles at 1 C. These studies explore the application of bimetallic NiCo phosphide materials for catalyzing lithium polysulfides, providing a new option for the next generation of high-performance LSBs. The high-valence Co sites on the surface of CoP can react with short-chain LiPSs to form Co–S bonds. FeP selectively catalyzes liquid-solid conversion. Zhang et al. [95] designed and prepared a composite material of heterogeneous bimetallic phosphides and graphene oxide (FeP-CoP/GO) as an efficient catalyst (Fig. 10C). FeP-CoP, as a catalyst, exhibited the well synergistic effects. It not only promoted the deposition of Li2S and improved sulfur utilization, but also possessed strong adsorption capacity for LiPSs. It also could provide sufficient active sites for anchoring and catalyzing conversion of LiPSs, thereby inhibiting their “shuttle effect” and enhancing the overall performance of the battery. Additionally, graphene oxide (GO) with good conductivity and abundant porous structure facilitated Li+ transport and reduces volume expansion. The composite material possessed a large specific surface area and an ample number of active sites, which were advantageous for the immobilization and adsorption of LiPSs. Its intricate porous structure facilitated the transport of ions and electrons, thereby enhancing the utilization of elemental sulfur. Additionally, the catalytic performance of this material was crucial for accelerating the kinetics of redox reactions. Benefiting from the outstanding adsorption-catalytic performance of bimetallic phosphide materials, in the presence of FeP-CoP/GO/S, the assembled cell exhibited good cycling stability and rate capability. The Mott-Schottky heterostructure is capable of redistributing charges to achieve an appropriate electronic structure. Zhang et al. [96] proposed a Mott-Schottky catalyst based on bimetallic phosphide CoFeP nanocrystals. The catalyst was decorated on a novel nanotube t-CN through a simple self-assembly process. Although each material has advantages in terms of adsorption sites and available specific surface area (SSA), the combination of the two materials within the CoFeP@CN heterostructure awakens a significant synergistic effect, significantly enhancing the adsorption and catalytic activity towards LiPSs. The Mott-Schottky heterostructure formed by the CoFeP@CN composite material can redistribute charges and achieve an appropriate electronic structure. The abundant sulfur/lithium-affinitive sites in the prepared CoFeP and t-CN enable superior adsorption performance for LiPSs. Furthermore, modifying the electron distribution within the heterostructure can lower the potential barrier and improve the redox kinetics during the charge/discharge process, including LiPSs phase transition and Li2S2/Li2S deposition/dissolution. Moreover, the porous tubular geometry of the CoFeP@CN composite material facilitated the diffusion of Li ions, accommodated volume changes during the reaction and provided abundant lithium/sulfur-affinitive sites to effectively capture soluble LiPSs. The prepared S@CoFeP@CN electrode exhibited high sulfur utilization, demonstrating superior rate performance and cycling stability. Prussian Blue analogs (PBAs), composed of metal ions and organic ligands, are widely used as ideal templates for the transformation of various porous or hollow metal phosphide materials. FeP can provide strong chemical bonding for LiPSs, and Ni2P nanoparticles also can mitigate the shuttle effect of soluble LiPSs. Chen et al. [97] designed and synthesized the hollow double-shelled Ni-Fe-P/N-doped carbon nanoboxes (defined as Ni-Fe-P/NC) as cathode materials for LSBs using PBA as a precursor and a simple phosphorization process (Fig. 10D). The double-shell structure and internal cavities formed by the reaction of PBA can provide larger buffer space. The unique structure not only alleviated volume changes during cycling and prevented the aggregation of Ni-Fe-P/NC, but also offered an effective surface area for liquid electrolyte penetration. Bimetallic phosphide materials with multiple active sites can anchor LiPSs through strong chemical adsorption, and N-doped carbon derived from CN- can generate defect sites, exposing more active sites. In addition, N-doped carbon exhibited good physical adsorption of polysulfides and high electron conductivity. Ni-Fe-P/NC, as a cathode material, effectively suppresses the migration of LiPSs, and the hollow double-shell structure accommodates sulfur in its cavity space, mitigating volume expansion. Therefore, the assembled LSBs with Ni-Fe-P/NC as the cathode exhibited good cycling stability. It is worth noting that the addition of bimetallic phosphide nanoparticles to the cathode material can be expected to enhance the effective adsorption of LiPSs. Song et al. [98] successfully prepared Fe-Ni-P@nitrogen-doped carbon (Fe-Ni-P@NC) composite material through a simple one-step phosphorization process and used it as a sulfur host for LSBs (Fig. 10E). The abundant bimetallic phosphide particles in the Fe-Ni-P@NC composite material can enhance the adsorption of lithium ions, effectively facilitating their conversion in LSBs. Additionally, the N-doped carbon generated by CN- from PBAs can improve the electrode’s conductivity. The results demonstrated the assembled LSBs with the S@Fe-Ni-P@NC composite material as the cathode can cycle more than 500 times at 1 C with a stable Coulombic efficiency of around 93%. The electronic structure of metal compounds can be controlled through heterostructure engineering, enabling stronger chemical interaction with LiPSs and suppressing the shuttle effect. Furthermore, incorporating highly conductive materials like metals can greatly enhance the electron transfer capacity of composite materials, thus improving the sluggish kinetics of charge-discharge reactions. Guo et al. [99] proposed a CoMo1- x P/Mo heterostructure as the main sulfur host for LSBs. By growing metallic Mo in situ, the CoMo1- x P/Mo heterostructure was created to adjust the electronic structure of CoMoP and enhance conductivity, facilitating electron transfer and accelerating redox kinetics. The introduction of Mo led to increased conductivity, while the CoMo1- x P/Mo heterostructure effectively suppressed the shuttle effect through interactions with LiPSs, resulting in improved cycling stability. Therefore, CoMo1- x P/Mo/S demonstrated outstanding long-term cycling performance. In conclusion, bimetallic phosphides possess unique polar characteristics and tunable electronic configurations, which make them highly promising as positive electrode materials for lithium-sulfur batteries. When compared to oxides and sulfides, the anionic attraction of phosphorus atoms in TMPs is relatively weaker towards electrons. The presence of P anions also can facilitate electron exchange and the kinetics of S6 2−/S2− redox reactions at the interfaces. Some studies also have suggested that the unoccupied d orbitals of transition metal cations can be served as essential active sites for fast charge transfer and heterogeneous redox reactions. At the atomic or molecular level, the unoccupied d orbitals of transition metal cations match with the p orbitals of nonmetal anions, providing an advantageous d/p orbital hybridization in the active metal centers when compared to the p orbitals’ hybridization with LiPSs. Therefore, transition metal phosphides with these special structures can greatly improve the conversion kinetics of LiPSs and effectively suppress the growth of lithium dendrites. However, the development of metal phosphides is greatly hindered by issues such as large volume changes and kinetic lag. Researchers commonly employ surface coating or encapsulation materials to enhance the conductivity and stability of electrodes, as well as regulate the nanostructure to alleviate volume expansion issues. Additionally, bimetallic compositions (NiCo, CoFe, NiFe, etc.) and their composites also can improve cycling stability and capacity retention. These measures aim to improve the performance of metal phosphides as cathode materials for lithium-sulfur batteries and drive advances in battery technology. The detailed information of Li-S batteries with the electrodes using bimetallic phosphides is presented in Table S4, which the summary will play the positive role for further the electrochemical performance of LSBs. 3.2.5 Bimetallic nitrides and carbides Transition metal nitrides (TMNs) such as CoN [100], VN [101], TiN [102] and NbN [103] possess unique electronic structures, high conductivity, excellent chemical stability and outstanding electrocatalytic activity. Bimetallic nitrides are a type of transition metal interstitial compound which mainly contains numerous vacancies, providing more active sites for catalytic processes. Due to the synergistic effects between the two metals, bimetallic nitrides exhibit significantly improved activity and stability when compared to their respective monometallic counterparts. Yan et al. [104] successfully designed and synthesized a nitrogen source-free Co3Mo3N with a sea urchin-like morphology, which was used for the first time as a sulfur host material in the assembled LSBs (Fig. 11 A). It was clearly demonstrated that the obtained Co3Mo3N can effectively anchor and catalyze the conversion of LiPSs, accelerating the electrochemical redox process and suppressing LiPSs shuttling. Due to these advantages, the prepared S@Co3Mo3N cathode demonstrated high-rate performance with a capacity of 705 mA h g−1 at 3 C rate and exhibited excellent cycling stability over 600 cycles with a low capacity decay rate of 0.08% per cycle at 1 C rate. Even with a high sulfur loading of 5.4 mg cm−2, it still can provide a high initial areal capacity of 4.50 mA h cm−2, which remained at 3.64 mA h cm−2 after 120 cycles. At the same time, C co-doped with Fe-N and Co-N can be utilized for catalyzing the conversion of long-chain polysulfides (S8 ↔ Li2S4) and short-chain LiPSs (Li2S4 ↔ Li2S), respectively. Ye et al. [105] reported a novel iron-cobalt bimetallic nitride composite carbon material (Fe-N/Co-N@C) that successfully integrated stepwise catalysis for both long-chain and short-chain LiPSs conversion reactions (Fig. 11B). The bimetallic system, comprising two catalysts integrated on carbon, exhibited non-coordinated Fe and Co dual active sites (Fe-N/Co-N). These dual active sites minimize the diffusion of LiPSs between different sites, thereby enhancing the efficiency of stepwise electrocatalysis in the overall S8 ↔ Li2S n ↔ Li2S reaction. And the Fe-N/Co-N@C, as a catalyst for LiPSs, can effectively improve battery performance, demonstrating higher catalytic activity and faster LiPSs conversion kinetics in LSBs. Therefore, the prepared Fe-N/Co-N@C sulfur cathode exhibited a remarkably high initial sulfur utilization rate of 94% and demonstrated excellent cycling stability with a capacity retention of 67% after 2000 cycles at a 2 C rate. Transition metal carbides (TMCs), such as TiC [106], MoC [107] and WC [108] possess unique metallic properties which not only can enhance the conductivity of the sulfur cathode, but also effectively inhibit the blocking of LiPSs through strong bonding. Zhao et al. [109] successfully prepared the Co3W3C@C@CNTs/S material through a simple one-step pyrolysis method and used it as a cathode in LSBs. The acid-treated carbon nanotubes also exhibited good dispersibility in aqueous solutions and excellent adsorption capacity for positively charged metal ions due to the presence of abundant oxygen-containing functional groups on their surfaces. After the carburization treatment, the prepared Co3W3C was firmly anchored onto the surface of carbon nanotubes, which helped to improve the conductivity and stability of the material. The polar Co3W3C can form strong interactions with the LiPSs intermediates, effectively suppressing their “shuttle effect” of LiPSs, increasing the utilization of the sulfur cathode and maintaining capacity and cycling stability. The excellent electrochemical performance of Co3W3C@C@CNTs can be attributed to the synergistic effects between Co3W3C and CNTs. The high activity and stability of the bimetallic carbide Co3W3C enabled the electrode material to exhibit excellent rate performance and cycling stability. Heterostructures can combine two materials with independent electronic structures, harnessing the advantages of both by modulating them at the molecular level. The obtained results in a heterostructure which incorporates the benefits of the two materials and further activates new properties at the reactive heterointerface. Various heterostructures such as MoC/MoO x [110], MoO2/Mo2N [111] and Fe3C/FeN [112] etc. have been demonstrated to effectively enhance the electrochemical redox of sulfur. Wang et al. [113] designed and synthesized a composite material composed of N-doped carbon nanofibers (CNF) embedded with bimetallic compounds using collagen fibers (CF) derived from biomass as the structural template (Fig. 11C). Metal anions WO4 2− and MoO4 2− were grafted onto the CF modified with plant polyphenols, which were then converted in-situ to WN/Mo2C and implanted into the CNF matrix, resulting in the preparation of the WMCNF. The obtained WN/Mo2C exhibited quantum size effects and a uniform distribution, maximizing the exposure of active sites. N-doped CNF derived from the CF precursor can be served as a conductive matrix, providing a rapid pathway for electron transfer. The formed WN/Mo2C compounds were ultra-fine nanoparticles with diameters of only 1–2 nm, and they were embedded in the CNF matrix in-situ. Furthermore, the heterostructure of the bimetallic composite material facilitated unique electronic interactions, synergistically promoting the adsorption and catalytic functions of WN and Mo2C in the WMCNFs composite, thus activating their catalytic capabilities in liquid-liquid and liquid-solid transformations and effectively accelerating the electrochemical kinetics of LiPSs conversion. The modified WM/PP separator exhibited superior catalytic performance, excellent suppression of LiPSs diffusion and outstanding lithium-ion diffusion property. Through numerous electrochemical characterizations, the obtained WM/PP demonstrated excellent cycling and rate capabilities, surpassing the performance of individual metal compounds (W/PP and M/PP). Combining these advantages, when used simultaneously as a separator modifier and sulfur host, the prepared WMCNFs composite materials exhibited exceptional cycling stability, with a cycle retention rate of 91.45% after 500 cycles at 2 C and still delivering a discharge capacity of up to 552.75 mA h g−1 at 10 C. Furthermore, the prepared WMCNFs-modified pouch cells exhibited rapid charging response rates and stable energy storage capabilities. In conclusion, TMCs and TMNs are highly attractive due to their excellent properties such as remarkable chemical stability and conductivity. Additionally, TMCs and TMNs are known as “interstitial alloys” formed by integrating carbon or N atoms into the interstices of the parent metal. The orbital hybridization between metal and non-metal elements broadens the d-band of the parent metal, imparting them with electron structures and catalytic properties similar to noble metals. Therefore, TMCs and TMNs can regulate catalytic functionality and reaction kinetics in the LSBs. Moreover, these compounds are considered suitable adsorbents by forming metal-sulfide bonds with moderate adsorption energies, preventing excessive confinement of intermediates which can hinder continuous electrochemical reactions due to sluggish redox kinetics. The detailed information of LSBs with the electrodes using bimetallic nitrides and carbides is presented in Table S5, which the summary will have some good guidances for further the electrochemical properties of LSBs. 3.2.6 Bimetallic MOFs Metal-organic framework materials (MOFs) are a type of porous material composed of metal ions and organic ligands, known for their extremely high specific surface area. Due to the ordered crystalline structure of MOFs, carbon-based composites derived from MOFs exhibit more uniform and tunable porosity when compared to traditional carbon materials such as carbon nanotubes and graphene. They also have been widely used as templates for the preparation of metal-containing or heteroatom-doped porous carbon materials. Nanocomposites prepared using MOFs as precursors demonstrate superior characteristics when compared to nanocomposites prepared using traditional methods. For instance, MOFs possess a large specific surface area and a diverse range of organic ligands. During the calcination process, a significant amount of small gaseous molecules is released from the applied MOFs, resulting in composites with a larger specific surface area. Using ZIF-8 as a sacrificial template to promote the in-situ growth of micropores is a commonly employed strategy. The Zn precursor is reduced and evaporated during the carbonization process, resulting in a hierarchical porous structure with uniformly distributed nanoscale particles. These micropores can physically confine LiPSs and enhance the transport of lithium ions and electrons. At the same time, ZIF-67, composed of tetrahedral coordinated divalent Co2+ ions and imidazole ligands, effectively captures LiPSs through strong chemical bonding with Co ions. Bimetallic Co/Zn MOFs can obtain uniformly distributed nanoparticles after the carbonization treatment, providing abundant active sites to accelerate the redox reactions of LiPSs and effectively prevent their dissolution and diffusion for LiPSs. Lu et al. [114] synthesized the ZnCo-MOF-5 microcubes via a reflux synthesis, followed by carbonization to transform them into a Co@graphitic carbon-porous composite (Co@GC-PC) with a large surface area (Fig. 12 A), which was used as the sulfur host to improve the performance of LSBs. The large surface area and sufficient mesopores of Co@GC-PC enabled the adsorption of LiPSs, while the electronic conductivity originates from the uniformly distributed Co and graphitic carbon. And the DFT calculations demonstrated that Co can effectively promoted the decomposition of Li2S. The catalytic activity of Co enhanced the charging process and minimizes polarization. Jeon et al. [115] synthesized N-doped hollow carbon composites embedded with well-dispersed Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles (Co/Co3O4-NHC) through the carbonization of Zn/Co bimetallic-organic framework/ZnO nanospheres (Fig. 12B). The prepared Co/Co3O4-NHC exhibited homogeneous N-doping, intertwined carbon nanotubes and dual porosity. The ZnO nanospheres used as the hollow structure template also can contribute to the formation of carbon nanotubes and micropores, which physically confined LiPSs and enhanced the transport of lithium ions and electrons. Furthermore, the carbonization of bimetallic Co/Zn MOFs also can provide uniformly distributed Co/Co3O4 nanoparticles in the N-doped carbon matrix, offering abundant active sites to accelerate the redox reactions of sulfur species and prevent the dissolution and diffusion of LiPSs. The S-infused Co/Co3O4-NHC cathode exhibited outstanding rate performance with a specific capacity of 447.9 mA h g−1 at 5 C, and it demonstrated stability with a capacity of 553.4 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles. Even with a high sulfur loading of 4 mg cm−2, it still retained 87.8% of its specific capacity after 250 cycles. In general, 3D conductive frameworks can facilitate rapid electron conduction. Yu et al. [116] developed a3D interconnected and open porous carbon network (3D CN) with abundant Co and N doping, as well as graphitic carbon species through the self-assembly of Zn/Co bimetallic ZIF nanoparticles and subsequent pyrolysis. The prepared unique structure enabled smooth mass transport due to the open porous structure, rapid electron conduction due to the 3D conductive framework and fast Li+ conduction due to the unique structure of ultra-thin sulfur coating, facilitating the adsorption and conversion of LiPSs on the host surface. In addition, Cheng et al. [117] synthesized a 3D layered structure of Co, NG@CNT matrix as a multifunctional sulfur host for LSBs (Fig. 12C). The novel hybrid structure mainly consists of densely distributed small-diameter carbon nanotubes connected by graphene sheets, providing a high specific surface area and a large nanoscale pore volume for sulfur encapsulation. Moreover, the robust framework constructed by the covalent connections combining with the local flexibility of graphene and carbon nanotubes also can effectively accommodate the volume changes of enclosed sulfur species. More importantly, the high content of N-doping agent and Co-N x -C species in Co, the prepared NG@CNT not only immobilized LiPSs through chemical adsorption, but also promoted the conversion reactions of LiPSs. These synergistic effects imparted the Co, NG@CNT/S electrode with high initial discharge capacity and high-rate performance. Due to these synergistic effects, the Co, NG@CNT/S composite material exhibited a high sulfur utilization rate (1398 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C), excellent rate performance (611 mA h g−1 at 6 C), and outstanding cycling stability (retaining 659 mA h g−1 even after 1500 cycles at 1 C). The cascaded structure is a complex and stable structure with a high specific surface area and excellent conductivity, thus enabling sufficient sulfur loading and reducing the impact of huge volume expansion during charge and discharge processes. Zheng et al. [118] designed and proposed a cascaded cobalt-zinc bimetallic carbon nanomaterial (Co, Zn-C-C) as a sulfur cathode. The Co, Zn-C-C provided strong chemical bonding and efficient catalytic activity for LiPSs. Additionally, the complex carbon structure of Co, Zn-C-C restricted the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and reduced volume expansion, resulting in excellent rate performance and cycling stability. 2D transition metal carbides (MXenes) usually possess excellent electronic conductivity, chemical durability and a unique layered structure. The polar surface of MXene, such as Ti3C2T x , can effectively bind LiPSs through Lewis acid sites. Wang et al. [119] reported the synthesis of MCoNPCNS as a cathode material by in-situ self-assembly of Co/Zn-ZIF on 2D MXene nanosheets, following by carbonizing and etching treatment. The obtained MCoNPCNS combining the advantages of internal MXene nanosheets and surface porous carbon, providing a stable structure and an ideal specific surface area. Furthermore, the co-doping of Co and N effectively enhanced the adsorption capacity for LiPSs and promoted the reaction kinetics of LiPSs. Moreover, the unique structure of the integrated MCoNPCNS/S-M-PP electrode can further suppresses the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and reduce the weight of the battery, leading to excellent electrochemical performance. N-doped carbon materials have been a hot research topic. Zhou et al. [120] cleverly utilized the thermal stability difference between ZIF-67 and ZIF-8 to synthesize the CNTs-grafted nitrogen-doped carbon@graphitic carbon nanocages (CNT-NC@GC) through the pyrolysis of the core-shell ZIF-8@ZIF-67 (Fig. 12D). The rationally designed material, serving as a sulfur host, exhibits multiple structural advantages. Firstly, the carbon shell with high porosity and large specific surface area provided sufficient space for high sulfur loading and greatly shortened the distance for ion/electron transfer, resulting in CNT-NC@GC/S with sulfur content close to 80% and improved utilization of the active material. Secondly, the introduction of carbon nanotubes enabled the formation of a 3D integrated conductive network among different particles and within the nanocages, thus enhancing electron conductivity and facilitating the full utilization of sulfur. The conductive network also usually possesses strong mechanical toughness, capable of accommodating the volume changes of the active material during discharge/charge processes. Lastly, the N-doping and embedded Co nanoparticles also can increase the surface adsorption sites, improving the ability to adsorb LiPSs into the highly porous carbon matrix. Furthermore, the embedded Co nanoparticles exhibited electrocatalytic activity, accelerating the conversion of LiPSs. The electronic structures of Co and Ni valence electrons are identical, which determines their similar electrochemical properties. Transition metal Co and Ni, with their high coordination numbers when coordinating with organic ligands, can be used to design and synthesize various novel MOFs. Li et al. [121] prepared a nickel-cobalt embedded nitrogen-doped carbon framework (CoNi-NC) through the pyrolysis of MOF precursors. The composite material inherited the advantages of the metal-organic framework, including a unique macroporous structure and a high specific surface area. The incorporation of nickel and cobalt significantly enhanced the charge-discharge capacity of the materials. The synergistic effect of the bimetallic composition, unique N-rich porous structure, abundant electrically active Ni-NC sites and Co-based phase effectively suppresses the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs during the charge-discharge process. As a result, the assembled LSBs exhibited excellent rate performance and cycling stability. (Al)MIL-53 possesses a highly porous network and a high pyrolysis temperature. The tetracoordinated Cu2+ ions have a strong binding tendency with LiPSs, effectively preventing the dissolution of Li2S x during the cyclic discharge/charge process. Geng et al. [122] selected Al-MOF as the sulfur host material and used Cu2+ as the second metal ion to prepare a bimetallic Al/Cu-MOF as the cathode materials (Fig. 12E). In this bimetallic MOF, Cu2+ is uniformly dispersed in Al-MOF, serving as both an ion cross-linker and a chemical binder for sulfide anions. The obtained bimetallic Al/Cu-MOF exhibited a high initial capacity of 974.2 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C. Through Lewis acid-base interactions, the prepared Al/Cu-MOF can provide effective binding sites for LiPSs and strongly confines them within the MOF pores, effectively mitigating their “shuttle effect”. Therefore, THE LSBs assembled with Al/Cu-MOF cathodes demonstrate higher specific capacities when compared to Al-MOF-S. Bimetallic MOFs significantly alter the inherent properties of the original MOFs, and bimetallic MOFs with high porosity and abundant Lewis acid active sites can enhance the electrochemical performance of MOFs. Li et al. [123] synthesized multi-metal nanocubes, MnM-MIL-100 (M = Mg2+, Ca2+, Al3+, Fe3+, Cr3+, Co2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Sr2+, Sn2+, Ba2+, Ce3+, Pb2+ and Bi3+), and trimetallic MIL-100 (MnNiCu-MIL-100 and MnNiCo-MIL-100), using a convenient hydrothermal method (Fig. 12F). This approach allowed the incorporation of metal ions which cannot be directly prepared into the MIL-100 structure of the monometallic MOF nanocubes, thus rationally generating novel multi-metal MOFs. By combining X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy with DFT calculations, the intrinsic properties of the bimetallic MOFs containing Mn and Ni nodes were revealed. Finally, the prepared MnNi-MIL-100@S exhibited the best performance in Li-S batteries with initial capacity of 1579.8 mA h g−1, along with excellent cycling stability and rate capability. In addition, Li et al. [124] successfully synthesized a novel sulfur-containing bimetallic Fe2Co-TPDC with two helical structures. Notably, due to its structural stability and excellent electrochemical performance, the prepared Fe2Co-TPDC can be served as a cathode. Thanks to the uniform distribution of active sulfur sites and the structural stability provided by the mixed metal approach, the prepared Fe2Co-TPDC framework not only prevented sulfur shuttle behavior and rapid capacity decay, but also enabled fast Li+ insertion/deinsertion kinetics. In conclusion, the high dispersibility of metal nodes in MOFs and the abundance of ligand elements allow for flexible and tunable metal elements and highly dispersed catalytic centers in nanocomposites derived from MOFs. Additionally, MOF-derived nanoporous carbon materials are lightweight and exhibit good conductivity, effectively enhancing the electrode’s conductivity. The unique structure of porous polyhedra and the incorporation of heteroatoms can effectively increase the number of pores and the uniform distribution of active sites. Bimetallic MOFs with high porosity and rich Lewis acidic active sites also can tightly bind LiPSs. All of these advantages significantly increase the sulfur loading, enhance the chemical adsorption of LiPSs, and improve the rate performance and cycling stability of LSBs. The detailed information of LSBs with the electrodes using bimetallic MOFs is presented in Table S6, which will provide researchers more guidances for further improving the electrochemical performance of LSBs. 3.2.7 Others Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are highly promising sulfur hosts in LiPSs. Metal hydroxides can strongly adsorb LiPSs by forming lithium-hydroxide and metal-sulfur bonds, and their unique 2D layered structure provides a large surface area and good porosity, which is advantageous for energy storage and conversion [125]. LDH materials usually possess several advantages for LSBs. Firstly, the partial isomorphous substitution of high-valence metals contributes to positively charged surface bands, allowing for electrostatic capture of LiPSs. Secondly, the high proportion of surface atoms in the atomic-level 2D structure enables efficient utilization of active sites for host-guest interactions. More importantly, the abundant hydroxyl groups on the LDH surface are highly lithiophilic and can serve as adsorption sites for LiPSs. Qiu et al. [126] developed a unique micro-nano hierarchical structure of bimetallic NiCo-LDH as an advanced sulfur reservoir for LSBs (Fig. 13 A). Compared to the monometallic Co-LDH, the introduction of Ni regulated the hydrolysis and nucleation behaviors during the chemical etching and re-precipitation process, contributing to the downsizing and vertical arrangement of hollow polyhedra in the NiCo-LDH, thus enriching the interfacial exposure for host-guest interactions. Furthermore, the bimetallic structure can endow the LDH with excellent solid sulfur immobilization and catalytic performance when compared to monometallic structures. Building upon these reasons, the obtained material was fully encapsulated by the rGO shell (NiCo-LDH@rGO), forming a tightly aggregated micro-nanocluster structure which can ensure fast long-distance electrons/ions conduction and stable structural integrity. Due to these structural and chemical advantages, the assembled Li-S batteries based on the prepared NiCo-LDH@rGO exhibited excellent cycling performance, with over 800 cycles and a minimal capacity decay of 0.04% per cycle. The rate performance reached as high as 2 C. Additionally, when the sulfur loading was increased to 5.5 mg cm−2, a highly reversible areal capacity of 4.3 mA h cm−2 can be achieved. Perovskite bimetallic hydroxides exhibit balanced chemical adsorption capacity and enhanced catalytic activity towards LiPSs conversion. Wang et al. [127] designed and prepared a hollow nanocage structure of perovskite bimetallic hydroxide (CoSn(OH)6) which was further encapsulated by reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as the catalytic host for sulfur cathodes (G@CSOH). Due to the coordination states of Co and Sn and inherent defects in the perovskite structure, this bimetallic hydroxide possessed moderate adsorption capacity and enhanced catalytic activity for LiPSs conversion. Additionally, the hollow structure and encapsulated rGO also can be acted as dual physical barriers, limiting the outward diffusion of LiPSs and ensuring their full and fast conversion. Therefore, the assembled LSBs utilizing the G@CSOH as the sulfur host exhibited excellent cycling stability, improved redox reaction kinetics and enhanced sulfur utilization. The assembled battery demonstrated excellent rate performance, achieving a high capacity of 644 mA h g−1 at 2 C, and exhibited long-term stability with a capacity decay of only 0.068% per cycle after more than 600 cycles at 1 C. Transition metal selenides (TMSes) have good catalytic properties, electrical conductivity, lithiophilicity, and sulfiphilic properties [128], and have become a research hotspot, which is expected to be a new generation of efficient catalysts for LSBs. MXenes are an emerging class of two-dimensional metal carbides and nitrides with excellent electrical conductivity, an abundance of polar functional groups and excellent mechanical flexibility. Ye et al. [129] achieved the self-assembly of MOFs on MXene nanosheets and utilized an in-situ selenization strategy to fabricate the 0D bimetallic selenides (CoZn-Se@N-MX) on 2D nitrogen-doped MXene (Fig. 13B). The combination of 0D CoZn-Se nanoparticles and 2D N-MX nanosheets can forme the dual-confined Li-S binding sites, effectively immobilizing and catalyzing the conversion of LiPSs intermediates. The MXene nanosheets, serving as catalytic substrates, not only can enable rapid electron and ion transport, but also prevent the aggregation of MOF-derived CoZn-Se nanoparticles during LiPSs conversion reactions. In turn, the MOF-derived selenides also can be acted as isolants to separate the MXene nanosheets and prevent restacking, thereby preserving the active regions required for the fast electrocatalysis of LiPSs. Moreover, the MOF-derived selenides effectively accelerated the redox reactions of LiPSs and enhance sulfur utilization. The 0D-2D heterogeneous catalyst with a layered porous structure exhibited a large active surface area, facilitating rapid Li+ diffusion, reducing the activation energy for Li2S deposition and lowering the energy barrier for Li2S dissolution. Consequently, the lithium sulfur cell assembled with N-doped MXene nanosheets loaded with MOF-derived selenides demonstrated outstanding rate performance, ultra-long cycle life (exceeding 2000 cycles), a high areal capacity of 6.6 mA h cm−2 and a low electrolyte/sulfur ratio of 5 µL mg−1. The presence of fluorides can promote the expansion of the electrochemical stability window, increase resistance to mechanical damage and enhance ion migration rates [130]. Introducing fluoride intermediate phases also can lead to chemical adsorption on LiPSs, accelerating liquid-liquid and solid-liquid reaction processes. Co and its compounds, as efficient catalysts, enable rapid catalytic conversion of LiPSs. Yttrium (Y), as a representative rare earth element, is believed to effectively limit the LiPSs effect and improve electrochemical performance due to its low electronegativity. Kang et al. [131] constructed YF3/CoF3 co-doped partially closed carbon nanofibers (PCNFs) as the sulfur cathode material for LSBs (Fig. 13C). The resulting 3D-structured PCNFs not only can provide a convenient pathway for electron transport, but also can enhance chemical adsorption of LiPSs by introducing nitrogen doping through polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as a carbon precursor. The YF3/CoF3 co-doped 1D porous carbon nanofibers exhibited a 3D interconnected network structure which incorporated the prepared nanoparticles. The YF3/CoF3 nanoparticles were uniformly distributed within the gradient porous conductive carbon skeleton, maximizing the exposure of more LiPSs binding active sites and presenting a greater number of catalytic sites, effectively suppressing the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and promoting oxidation-reduction reactions. Furthermore, the surface of the carbon nanofibers can be covered with a layer of microporous carbon, which can be acted as a physical constraint and chemical adsorbent for LiPSs. Additionally, the prepared PCNFs can further enhance the mechanical properties of the carbon skeleton, reducing volume expansion and effectively inhibiting collapse of the cathode structure during the redox reaction. Therefore, batteries assembled with this cathode material demonstrated stable and excellent electrochemical performance. The detailed information of Li-S batteries with the electrodes using bimetallic hydroxides, selenides and fluorides is presented in Table S7, which will provide some suggestions for further researching them in high performance LSBs. For the cathodes, the main focus of bimetallic modified materials is to enhance the solid-state storage capacity of sulfur and improve the conductivity of electrons and ions, thereby reducing the loss and polarization effects of sulfur species during battery operation. The cathode material emphasizes the design of a porous structure to accommodate dissolved LiPSs, and the introduction of polar materials and catalysts on the substrate also can strengthen the interaction between LiPSs and the substrate, effectively promoting the cathodic redox kinetics to anchor the LiPSs. Additionally, bimetallic materials used for the cathode still need to consider the huge volume expansion caused by long-chain LiPSs during the discharge process. In terms of the cathode, bimetallic materials also can enhance the adsorption and catalytic effects on LiPSs by adjusting the catalytic active sites and electronic structure, effectively promoting the transformation of LiPSs and improving the cycling stability and energy density of the battery. Bimetallic materials may have remarkable potential in protecting the lithium metal anode. The stability of the lithium metal anode limits the cycle life of Li-S batteries under practical working conditions. Under practical conditions, the uneven deposition and stripping of lithium metal are significant issues, resulting in the growth of lithium dendrites and the large formation of “dead lithium”. The “shuttle effect” of soluble LiPSs further corrodes the lithium metal anode, leading to the depletion of active lithium and rapid failure of the lithium metal anode. Some well strategies for protecting the lithium metal anode include promoting uniform lithium-ion deposition and stripping, reducing the concentration of LiPSs on the anode side and effectively reducing the reactivity between LiPSs and lithium metal. There are few studies on bimetallic materials in this aspect, but we believe that bimetallic materials have great prospects in serving as modified layers on the anode side of separators and composite lithium metal anodes. On one hand, adding a bimetallic functional layer on the anode side of the separator can effectively promote uniform lithium-ion deposition on the anode, stabilize the interface of the lithium metal anode, reduce the growth of lithium dendrites and enhance the mechanical properties of the cell separator. The inhibitory effect of the functional layer on LiPSs also can effectively alleviate the uneven deposition and corrosion of metal Li and sulfur species on the surface of cell anode. Therefore, constructing functional separators using bimetallic materials also can effectively protect the lithium metal anode. On the other hand, using carbon materials with high specific surface area and excellent conductivity, as well as bimetallic materials with outstanding electrochemical activity surfaces, as substrate materials for composite lithium metal anodes, is a feasible strategy. The transport flux of lithium ions in this composite lithium anode are more uniform, and the depletion time of Li+ on the conductive surface is prolonged, thereby alleviating the formation of lithium dendrites. Meanwhile, some 3D interconnected carbon material also can ensure the contact between the lithium metal and the conductive interface, preventing the large formation of “dead lithium”. The introduction of lithium-affinitive sites in bimetallic materials can further control the location and morphology of lithium deposition. Some metals can also form alloys with lithium metal, acting as lithiophilic sites to eliminate the deposition barrier of lithium metal, promote uniform lithium nucleation and enhance the cycle life of the lithium metal anode. In addition, it is worth mentioning that the introduction of non-active substances in the composite lithium metal anode may reduce its theoretical specific capacity, so the actual density of bimetallic composite materials needs to be considered when designing materials. In addition, the combining the application of bimetallic composite lithium anodes and other anode protection strategies is also essential to suppress “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and lithium metal side reactions. 3.3 Modified separators Separators are typically porous membranes made of insulating materials, placed between the anodes and cathodes to maintain their separation, prevent internal short circuits and allow the free movement of lithium ions. Currently, polypropylene (PP) separators are widely used due to their simple manufacturing process, high strength, and favorable porous structure for rapid Li+ transport. However, the prolonged application or high-rate charge and discharge operations may cause small holes or defects in the PP separator, potentially leading to electrolyte penetration and internal short circuits. In order to further enhance electrical insulation and safety, some additives or multi-layer structures are commonly used to improve the ability to resist the penetration of dendritic lithium metal. These are because the penetration of dendritic lithium metal can cause short circuits, leading to serious safety issues. Moreover, the pore size of the PP separator is too large, allowing the easy passage of intermediate products (LiPSs) generated during the charge and discharge process of LSBs. This inability to effectively suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSs leads to severe capacity decay. When compared to sulfur-based composite electrode structures, designing new functional separators for LSBs is an effective and straightforward method to inhibit the shuttle effect of LiPSs. Modifying the separator with functional materials enables rapid Li+ transport and restricts the shuttle of LiPSs, proving to be a simple and effective approach to suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSs and enhance energy density of the Li-S cell. Carbon materials possess good conductivity, mechanical strength and thermal stability, making them suitable candidates for separator modification to accelerate redox kinetics and improve the electrochemical performance of LSBs. Among carbon materials, conductive carbon frameworks such as porous carbon, graphene, and carbon nanotubes have been extensively studied. However, due to weak chemical interactions between carbon materials and LiPSs, non-polar carbon materials can only provide limited capability to inhibit the shuttle of LiPSs. Additionally, carbon materials are unable to maintain their original structural morphology and adsorb LiPSs for an extended period, leading to unstable long-term cycling performance of the battery. Therefore, many polar materials such as metal compounds and metal-organic frameworks have been used as additives to carbon materials to increase the polarity of the separator and enhance the anchoring of LiPSs. Although the combination of materials increases the binding strength, the catalytic conversion of adsorbed LiPSs to Li2S remains a challenge. Excessive accumulation of LiPSs leads to slow reaction kinetics and the formation of thick passivation layers, which can deteriorate the electrochemical performance of LSBs, especially under high sulfur loading and long-term cycling conditions. Currently, besides the simple barrier effect against LiPSs, the explanation of the modification mechanisms of the separator mainly focuses on adsorption or catalysis. Single adsorption or catalysis alone cannot effectively suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSs since the material’s adsorption capacity for LiPSs is limited, and catalysis requires the adsorption of LiPSs to active sites. On the one hand, if soluble LiPSs cannot be rapidly converted to insoluble short-chain LiPSs and re-deposited on the cathode, the active sites on the separator will be occupied, resulting in loss of active material and a significant decrease in the effectiveness of the modification layer. On the other hand, if the material’s adsorption capacity for LiPSs is weak, the formed LiPSs cannot fully contact the catalytic sites, thereby limiting the catalytic activity of the material. If the material’s adsorption capacity for LiPSs is too strong, LiPSs will be confined within the modified layer, reducing the utilization of active materials. Therefore, it is of great significance to balance the relationship between adsorption and catalysis, achieving continuous and efficient conversion of LiPSs to the cathode materials and targeted deposition. Generally, a metal compound usually exhibited either strong catalytic or strong adsorptive properties. Thus, the development of dual-functional separators being capable of both adsorbing and catalyzing LiPSs conversion is urgently needed. Bimetallic materials are widely utilized in the field of modified separators in Li-S batteries due to their excellent combinations of high adsorption capacities and strong catalytic activities. Generally, bimetallic materials are applied as functional coatings on separators to inhibit the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. By controlling the surface properties and interface interactions of bimetallic materials, excellent isolation and ion transport control can be achieved, leading to improved battery performance and safety. 3.3.1 Bimetallic alloys Transition metal-based alloys are considered promising sulfur-active materials due to their high electrochemical conductivities and electrocatalytic activities. Iron is one of the most abundant elements in the Earth’s crust. More importantly, the ionic radius of Fe3+ is very similar to that of Co2+, and the electron shell structure of Fe is similar to that of Co. During the preparation process, it is easy to form Co-Fe alloys, thereby avoiding phase separation issues. CoFe alloys have been widely used in various fields, including zinc-air batteries, fuel cells and lithium-ion batteries due to their excellent catalytic activity. Gu et al. [132] designed and prepared the CoFe/NHCS nanocomposites and utilized them as efficient and stable electrocatalysts for LSBs (Fig. 14 B). Compared to Fe, the bimetallic alloy Co3Fe7 exhibited the enhanced chemical adsorption and electrocatalytic activity towards LiPSs. Additionally, N-doped hollow carbon spheres also can effectively promote the transport of Li+ and electrons while increasing the exposure of active sites. Moreover, the obtained CoFe/NHCS demonstrated excellent chemical properties and physical structure stability during extended electrochemical processes. Due to their synergistic advantages of the above-mentioned, the LSBs assembled with CoFe/NHCS-modified separators exhibited outstanding rate performance and cycling stability. The dual-metal organic framework pyrolysis strategy is an important approach for synthesizing bimetallic nanocomposite particles. Building upon this, Hu et al. [133] developed the CoFe alloy (CoFeCN@C) nanoparticles encapsulated with the N-doped carbon layers, which were utilized as a multifunctional separator in high performance LSBs (Fig. 14A). The polar CoFe alloy can provide sufficient chemical adsorption sites for immobilizing LiPSs and can be acted as an electrocatalyst to accelerate the redox conversion of LiPSs, thereby enhancing the electrochemical reaction kinetics and suppressing the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Additionally, the outer N-doped carbon layer facilitated the transport of lithium ions and electrons. The LSBs assembled with CoFeCN@C-modified separators exhibited high sulfur utilization and persistent cycling stability due to the synergistic effect of CoFe alloy and conductive carbon layer. Finally, the assembled batteries demonstrated excellent cycling stability even under high sulfur loading. Considering the excellent catalytic activity of the Co7Fe3 alloy, Zeng et al. [134] successfully prepared Co7Fe3@porous graphite carbon-carbon nanotube (Co7Fe3@PGC-CNT) composite materials using the sol-gel method (Fig. 14C). And the DFT calculations also were performed to estimate the interaction between graphene-coated Co7Fe3 alloy and LiPSs. The results indicated that the bimetallic Co7Fe3 can effectively promoted the anchoring of LiPSs, diffusion of Li+ and the lithiation of S8 to Li2S, strongly suggesting rapid redox conversion of LiPSs. The well-designed Co7Fe3@PGC-CNT composite material was introduced into LSBs through the separator modification. The results showed that the prepared Co7Fe3 bimetallic nanoparticles exhibited excellent catalytic activity during the oxidation-reduction process of LiPSs, and the assembled LSBs with the prepared Co7Fe3@PGC-CNT-modified separators demonstrated outstanding rate performance and long-term cycling stability. Transition metal Mn has been proven to have strong adsorption properties through the DFT calculations. It is worth noting that bimetallic systems can provide synergistic effects compared to their monometallic counterparts, optimizing electronic structure, increasing conductivity and reducing reaction barriers, thereby greatly enhancing catalytic activity through richer redox reactions. Luo et al. [135] selected Co with high catalytic activity and Mn with strong adsorption capability to modify the N-C material of the separator. The prepared Co/Mn bimetallic-modified graphene carbon (Co/Mn-GC@NC) anchored on N-doped carbon nanosheets was prepared using a salt template method and high-temperature calcination to catalyze the conversion of LiPSs and improve electrochemical performance. Nanoclusters containing multiple atoms exhibited excellent performance due to the high specific surface area. In addition, the coordination environment of transition metal electrocatalysts was considered an adjustable factor for optimizing catalytic performance. The obtained Co/Mn-GC@N-C possessed high conductivity and large specific surface area, providing a large number of active sites for anchoring LiPSs, stimulating their redox reactions and accelerating electrode reaction kinetics. Carbon nanotubes derived from the Co/Mn-GC@N-C exhibited excellent conductivity and large specific surface area. The unique coordination environment of the metal also can provide abundant catalytic active sites, enabling effective capture and catalytic conversion between LiPSs and elemental sulfur while also accelerating electron transfer, resulting in satisfactory electrochemical performance of LSBs. The synergistic effect of bimetallic nanoparticles often exhibits enhanced catalytic performance, making them widely applied in catalytic reactions. Luo et al. [136] ingeniously designed and fabricated CoNi bimetallic nanoparticles (CoNi@MPC) loaded on petal-like mesoporous carbon, which were used as a separator coating for LSBs (Fig. 14D). The prepared CoNi@MPC embeds bimetallic nanoparticles into a porous carbon conductive framework, creating Co-Ni bimetallic active sites which can catalyze the reaction of soluble LiPSs. The results can accelerate the formation and decomposition of insoluble LiPSs, effectively mitigating the “shuttle effect” of LIPSs. When compared to the monometallic Co@MPC and Ni@MPC materials, it was evident that CoNi@MPC can significantly reduce the polarization of the battery to a greater extent, enhancing the diffusion of lithium ions and decreasing the interfacial impedance. Meanwhile, the DFT calculations demonstrated that the energy required for Li2S bond breakage was lower on the surface of CoNi bimetal, indicating faster kinetics for Li2S decomposition. In summary, this bimetallic structure is more favorable for uniform nucleation of Li2S2/Li2S on its surface, exhibiting well catalytic activity in the generation and decomposition of Li2S, finally significantly improving the cycling performance and initial capacity during the charge-discharge process. Compared to highly crystalline nanomaterials, low-crystallinity or amorphous nanomaterials exhibit relatively unsaturated electronic configurations, a large number of randomly oriented bonds and abundant defect sites, which are advantageous for achieving efficient LiPSs catalysts by adjusting the crystallinity. Liu et al. [137] successfully synthesized low-crystallinity Ni x Fe y alloy nanoparticles (LC-Ni x Fe y ) grown on an oxygenated carbon nanotube/N-doped graphene network (OCNT/NG). These nanoparticles were uniformly coated on the surface of a PP separator, serving as a dual-functional separator with both sulfur affinity and lithium affinity for LSBs. The experimental results demonstrated that the abundant active sites of LC-Ni x Fe y @OCNT/NG on a large scale can effectively enhance the strong adsorption capacity and conversion kinetics of LiPSs, allowing uniform Li+ flux into the cathode. Additionally, the theoretical calculations also confirmed that the obtained LC-Ni x Fe y alloy exhibited high adsorption energy and low diffusion barriers for LiPSs along with a reduced band-gap and higher electron density near the Fermi level. When compared to the highly crystalline HC-Ni x Fe y @OCNT/NG, the prepared low-crystallinity LC-Ni x Fe y @OCNT/NG showed more significant improvements in the sulfur conversion kinetics and adsorption capacity towards LiPSs. By integrating the redox capability of LC-Ni x Fe y alloy with the 3D conductive network of OCNT/NG, the assembled LSBs loaded with LC-Ni x Fe y @OCNT/NG modified separator demonstrated high specific capacity, outstanding rate performance and long-term cycling stability. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) exhibit adjustable porosity and structure and nanocomposites prepared from MOFs as precursors have a large specific surface area. Due to the high dispersity and diversity of metal nodes in MOFs, as well as the abundance of ligand elements, the metal elements in the final composite materials are flexible and adjustable, and the catalytic centers are also highly dispersed. Zhou et al. [138] combined bimetallic Zn and Pd-ZIF-8 with CNT to prepare ZnPd/NCF through carburization treatment, where the ZnPd alloy nanoparticles were uniformly dispersed in a N-doped 3D conductive framework. The prepared 3D conductive network can provide a pathway for rapid electron transfer, while the bimetallic ZnPd alloy nanoparticles and N doping also can effectively adsorb LiPSs. The synergistic effect between the lithium-affinitive element Zn and sulfur-affinitive element Pd in ZnPd alloy imparted high catalytic activity towards LiPSs. Zinc can induce fast Li+ transfer, while palladium can adsorb and catalyze LiPSs, effectively facilitating the conversion of LiPSs. The obtained ZnPd/NCF composite material exhibited excellent chemical adsorption performance and catalytic activity, enabling the fast conversion of LiPSs under high current density or sulfur loading. The assembled LSBs coated with ZnPd/NCF as a separator exhibited outstanding performance, resulting in excellent rate capability. In conclusion, when used as a separator material in LSBs, bimetallic alloys can form favorable interface structures with sulfides, enhancing interface stability and bonding strength. This result can prevent the dissolution and diffusion of LiPSs and reduce the loss of sulfides, thus prolonging the cycle life of batteries. Bimetallic alloys exhibit good electrocatalytic activity and stable catalytic surfaces, promoting the reaction kinetics of sulfides and reducing the occurrence of polarization, thereby enhancing the cycle stability and energy density of the battery. Therefore, bimetallic alloys have some advantages in catalysis, polarization inhibition, interface stability and ion conductivity in LSBs. These advantages contribute to improving the energy density, cycle life and power performance of the battery, promoting the development and application of LSBs. It is worth noting that bimetallic alloys such as FeCo, FeNi, Co7Fe3, CoNi and CoMn exhibit outstanding electrochemical performance, including strong adsorption capability and electrocatalytic activity for LiPSs conversion. The detailed information of LSBs with the separators using bimetallic alloys is presented in Table S8, which will help researchers to further enhance these materials in the future for further improving the electrochemical performance of LSBs. 3.3.2 Bimetallic oxides Bimetallic oxides are commonly considered as effective candidates for energy storage systems and catalysts. As a typical transition metal oxide (TMO) material, NiCo2O4 has been investigated for the use as a cathode electrode in Li-S batteries, and this TMO material is believed to have catalytic acceleration effects. On one hand, NiCo2O4 is a TMO with high polarity affinity, which can help to promote the catalytic conversion of LiPSs during the recharge process and enhances the stability during cycling. On the other hand, lithium ions also exhibit low energy barriers and efficient transport on the surface of NiCo2O4, thereby improving the areal capacity of the battery. Lv et al. [139] synthesized a robust NiCo2O4@rGO composite material as a modified functional layer for the functional separators of LSBs. When compared to the commercialized PP separators, the NiCo2O4@rGO-coated PP (NiCo2O4@rGO/PP) separator had abundant polar NiCo2O4 particles on the porous rGO structure, providing rapid ion diffusion channels and abundant active sites for catalytic conversion of LiPSs. The DFT calculations demonstrated that NiCo2O4 exhibited a low energy barrier for Li+ diffusion. Therefore, the application of NiCo2O4@rGO/PP separators significantly improved the cycling performance. Incorporating defects into functional materials is an efficient method to enhance their catalytic ability and LiPSs affinity in LSBs. Constructing anion and cation vacancies is an effective approach to obtain defect materials. Building oxygen vacancies in bimetallic oxides can form effective defect structures and expose more active sites, thereby further enhancing the catalytic activity of functional materials. MnCo2O4, as a bimetallic oxide, possesses unique advantages in mitigating the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Its layered nanostructure with a hollow interior and porous shell can provide abundant active sites and sufficient space for insoluble LiPSs deposition. Wu et al. [140] designed and prepared a synergistic adsorption-catalytic functional layer composed of hollow porous MnCo2O4 nano-flowers with abundant oxygen vacancies (Fig. 15 A). The MnCo2O4 nano-flowers obtained through low-temperature calcination treatment exhibited richer oxygen vacancies. The oxygen vacancies in the spinel-type MnCo2O4 promoted the chemical interaction between MnCo2O4 and LiPSs, achieving stable anchoring of LiPSs. The functional coating also demonstrated rapid conversion kinetics of LiPSs, which improved sulfur utilization and prevented LiPSs accumulation on the separator surface. Furthermore, the layered nanostructure not only improved the electrolyte permeation, but also provided ample space for insoluble LiPSs deposition, ensuring sufficient channels for rapid Li+ transfer. Therefore, the battery using MnCo2O4@PP achieved highly stable cycling performance and high reversible capacity. Zhu et al. [141] designed and prepared a sea urchin-like structure of NiCo2O4 to expose more catalytic sites and accelerate the conversion of LiPSs (Fig. 15C). The oxygen defects in the spinel-type NiCo2O4 resulted in excellent chemical affinity of NiCo2O4- x towards LiPSs. Moreover, by adjusting the anion vacancies on the crystal surface of NiCo2O4- x , the charge distribution was reasonably regulated. Due to the optimal distribution of electrons on the NiCo2O4- x (311) crystal plane, the Gibbs free energy for the evolution from S8 to Li2S on the NiCo2O4- x (311) crystal plane was much lower than that of NiCo2O4, indicating higher catalytic activity of NiCo2O4- x . Finally, the assembled batteries equipped with NiCo2O4- x -modified separators exhibited excellent LiPSs conversion kinetics and strong chemical adsorption capability. Therefore, the battery utilizing the NiCo2O4- x -modified separators with abundant anion vacancies demonstrated outstanding cycle life and rate performance. Furthermore, cation vacancies can effectively enhance the anchoring and catalytic properties of multifunctional LiPSs-blocking layers. Li et al. [142] proposed a design strategy for anchoring functional materials through the cation vacancies and prepared zinc-deficient ZnCo2O4 (ZDZCO) nanosheets with zinc partially substituting cobalt and in situ etching to achieve zinc vacancies. The prepared ZDZCO was a bimetallic oxide rich in cation vacancies used for constructing multifunctional LiPSs-blocking layers. The theoretical and experimental studies have demonstrated that the ZDZCO with abundant cation vacancies exhibited strong binding ability to LiPSs and high catalytic activity for rapid the conversion of LiPSs. The composite separator formed by combining the multi-functional ZDZCO blocking layer with a commercial polypropylene separator can effectively contribute to achieving high sulfur loading and high areal capacity in LSBs. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) typically exhibit high atomic efficiency, unsaturated metal species, unique electronic structures, low mass density and minimal impact on the overall weight of the battery [143]. Additionally, SACs also can provide easier access to catalytic sites, allowing for greater adsorption and catalysis of LiPSs. However, when compared to many efficient catalysts, SACs do not necessarily excel in the practical catalytic performance for LiPSs. This is primarily due to the limitations of single-atom centers, which can only catalyze single-molecule elementary reactions. Song et al. [144] designed and synthesized a dual-nuclear single-atom catalyst (ZnCoN4O2/CN) consisting of atomically dispersed Zn-Co sites on carbon nanosheets with N and O coordination for separator coatings (Fig. 15D). At the Zn-Co-N/O sites, the formed interconnected Co and Zn atoms can bind with N and O ligands, forming a locally paired configuration. The DFT calculations also showed that in ZnCoN4O2/CN, the zinc sites exhibited lithium affinity, while the cobalt sites presented sulfur affinity, synergistically accelerating the conversion of LiPSs and Li+ migration. Furthermore, the prepared ZnCoN4O2/CN not only can promote Li+ transport and Li2S diffusion, but also more effectively suppressed LiPSs and catalyzed sulfur conversion reactions. The prepared ZnCoN4O2/CN integrated the advantages of the enhanced chemical adsorption of LiPSs, facilitated LiPSs conversion, Li+ migration and abundant Li2S2/Li2S deposition sites, thereby achieving rapid kinetics and high sulfur utilization. The assembled LSBs using the ZnCoN4O2/CN-modified separators demonstrated excellent rate performance and stable long-term cycling. In fact, for LiPSs, adsorption and catalysis only occur on the surface molecules of the catalyst. Thick separator-modifying materials are not conducive to improving the electrode energy density. Therefore, thinning the modified separator material is an important indicator of practical battery applications. It not only maximizes the utilization of the material, but also exposes abundant active sites with small particles, thereby improving the reaction kinetics. Pu et al. [145] prepared the ultra-thin 2D Fe-Co bimetallic oxide nanosheets using graphene as a template (Fig. 15E), which can rapidly catalyze the conversion and suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSs. The prepared CoFe2O exhibited a 2D structure which prevents particle aggregation during cycling. Moreover, the ultra-thin layered structure facilitated charge diffusion, and the wide-layered structure also can provide numerous active Fe and Co sites for completing the interaction with LiPSs. Additionally, this graphene-based ultra-thin nanoscale structure also can provide sufficient active sites and rapid diffusion pathways for lithium ions. Due to these advantages, the assembled LSBs with modified separators using ultra-thin 2D Fe-Co bimetallic oxide nanosheets exhibited high initial capacity and relatively slow capacity decay rate. Fe2O3 and V2O5 have been applied to immobilize LiPSs and catalyze their redox conversion in Li-S batteries. Cheng et al. [146] developed a nanocatalyst, FeVO4, with a 3D ordered structure of Fe and V coordination and modified a PP separator with conductive CNTs to achieve efficient suppression of LiPSs shuttle and promote the redox conversion of sulfur species. Due to the reconstruction of the 3d band, the bimetallic oxide of Fe and V coordination exhibited stronger anchoring and catalytic activity toward sulfur species when compared to the monometallic states of Fe2O3 and V2O5. Therefore, the FVO/CNT@PP separator with an ultra-thin (approximately 4 µm) and super-lightweight (0.24 mg cm−2) coating enabled the LSBs to deliver enhanced electrochemical performance, including initial capacity, coulombic efficiency, capacity retention, rate capability, reaction kinetics, self-discharge resistance, lithium-ion deposition, and lithium surface corrosion. It is noteworthy that Li-S pouch cells with the FVO/CNT@PP separator can provide an energy density of up to 341 W h kg−1 under practical conditions. Introducing defect sites provides an effective and flexible strategy for regulating the catalytic activity of materials. Zhao et al. [147] designed and prepared defective MnV2O6 (D-MVO) as a pre-catalyst for LiPSs adsorption and conversion (Fig. 15B). The introduction of surface V defects effectively accelerated the in-situ sulfidation of D-MVO during electrochemical cycling, thereby creating truly active sites for LiPSs acceleration. In-situ sulfidated D-MVO also exhibited higher electrocatalytic activity for the redox conversion of LiPSs when compared to defect-free MVO. The D-MVO effectively reduced the decomposition barrier of Li2S and prevented the accumulation of dead sulfur, ensuring the activity and durability of the electrocatalyst. With these advantages, the LSBs equipped with the D-MVO separators can achieve outstanding long-term cycling performance. Bidirectional catalysis is an effective strategy for increasing the cycle life of lithium-sulfur batteries. Most catalysts may only promote the reduction (discharge) of LiPSs and subsequent nucleation of Li2S, without actively influencing the oxidation (charge) of Li2S. However, the continuous cycling performance of a lithium-sulfur battery is an important evaluation criterion. Therefore, merely promoting the discharge reaction is insufficient. The discharge product, non-conductive solid Li2S, can accumulate on the active sites of the catalyst, leading to the deterioration of the electrochemical reaction interface and affecting the energy storage performance. Si et al. [148] synthesized MnO x -NiO x /C composite material by the high-temperature calcination treatment and cast them onto a PP separator. The MnO x -NiO x /C composite material catalyzed the reduction of Li2S x and the oxidation of Li2S by reducing the activation energy. During the discharge process of LSB, the applied MnO x primarily enhanced the chemical adsorption of LiPSs through S–Mn–O bonding, while the Ni2+/Ni0 redox couple in NiO x catalyzed and promoted the conversion of LiPSs through a parallel pathway mediated by LiPSs. The synergistic adsorption and catalytic effect between MnO x and NiO x can effectively enhanced the LiPSs-related reduction. During the charge process of LSB, the applied MnO x and NiO x also can be acted as catalysts by optimizing the nucleation and decomposition of Li2S (Li2S2/Li2S) and the oxidation of Li2S. Therefore, the assembled LSBs with the prepared MnO x -NiO x /C-modified PP separators can provide stable and attractive rate performance for long-term cycling. Recent some studies have shown that nanostructured NiFe2O4, primarily used as a lithium storage material, exhibits strong adsorption capabilities towards LiPSs. Jiang et al. [149] prepared battery separators based on NiFe2O4/Ketjen Black (KB) modification. The hydrophilic nature of NiFe2O4 nanoparticles can improve the wetting properties of the separator with the electrolyte. The prepared NiFe2O4 can effectively hinder the shuttle effect by utilizing its binding affinity and chemical adsorption towards LiPSs. The KB possessed excellent conductivity and the porous packing of particles retained numerous voids, providing pathways for ion transfer. Additionally, its flexible texture also can alleviate the volume expansion of the cathode and separator. The NiFe2O4/KB-modified battery separator not only enhanced the conductivity of the separator, but also effectively utilized a physical and chemical dual-layer adsorption mechanism to prevent LiPSs from escaping the LiPSs shuttle. Furthermore, it can fully exert its catalytic activity, improving the conversion efficiency of LiPSs and activating the trapped sulfur. Thermal stability is an important indicator for evaluating the safety performance of LSBs. The inherent non-flammability of NiFe2O4 and the excellent thermal stability of g-C3N4 can contribute to the enhanced safety of LSBs. Peng et al. [150] successfully achieved a heat-resistant separator with Li2Sn trapping/conversion capability by modifying a functionalized NiFe2O4 quantum dots (QDs)@g-C3N4 intermediate layer on a PP separator. As shown in Fig. 15(F), the intertwined and porous g-C3N4 nanofibers formed a layered “LiPSs-capturing” network, enabling strong chemical adsorption and effective interception of soluble LiPSs. The prepared NiFe2O4 quantum dots attached to the g-C3N4 nanofibers exhibited significant catalytic performance towards anchored LiPSs, with their uniform distribution providing the interlayer with more abundant catalytic active sites. Moreover, the layered film of NiFe2O4 QDs@g-C3N4 demonstrated the smooth Li+ transport/electron transfer capabilities and good mechanical tolerance against lithium dendrite growth. Lastly, but equally important, the inherent non-flammability of NiFe2O4 and the high melting point of g-C3N4 nanofibers also can contribute to reducing the combustion risk of LSBs. Compared to the thermally less stable bare PP separator, the modified separator showed no significant structural deformation even at 170 °C. Therefore, the filling of LSBs with NiFe2O4 QDs@g-C3N4/PP separator exhibited significantly enhanced cycling performance and operational lifespan. The calcium titanate LaNiO3 prepared using the sol-gel technique exhibits excellent catalytic performance and structural stability, making it widely applicable in electrode materials, conductive transparent films, catalysis, sensors, and other fields. Wang et al. [151] utilized LaNiO3 as a modified material to construct a three-in-one composite membrane, aiming to enhance the electrochemical stability and redox kinetics of lithium-sulfur batteries. LaNiO3 material possesses exceptional conductivity, facilitating fast electronic transfer of adsorbent polysulfides. Simultaneously, LaNiO3 material exhibits favorable adsorption effects on LiPSs, effectively inhibiting LiPSs shuttling during the charge-discharge process. Most importantly, LaNiO3 material demonstrates remarkable catalytic capability for polysulfide conversion, significantly improving the redox kinetics. The three-in-one composite membrane not only hinders the polysulfides, but also rapidly converts them without aggregation, thus ensuring its durability. Therefore, batteries equipped with LaNiO3-loaded membranes exhibit excellent and stable cycling performance. Just like in the case of cathode materials, bimetallic oxides have also received extensive attention and research as separator materials. It is worth noting that some studies have shown that oxygen defect structures not only enhance the electronic conductivity of bimetallic oxides on the side of the cathode, but also improve their catalytic ability by adjusting the electronic structure. Therefore, it is a good strategy to enhance the reaction activity of catalysts by properly adjusting the anion vacancies in bimetallic oxides. The detailed information of LSBs with the separators using bimetallic oxides is presented in Table S9, which will provide some guidances for further researching them in high performance LSBs. 3.3.3 Bimetallic sulfides Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) are considered as potential separator coating materials due to their excellent adsorption and catalytic capabilities towards LPSs. The hollow structure with pores not only buffers the volume variation of TMSs, but also absorbs and stores a large amount of LPSs, thereby further enhancing the cycling performance of LSBs. Jin et al. [152] synthesized hollow-structured molybdenum sulfide/cobalt sulfide mixed amorphous carbon nanoparticles (MoS2/Co9S8/C) using the ZIF-67 as a precursor and applied them as functional co[atings for the separators of LSBs (Fig. 16 A). The outer layer of MoS2 in MoS2/Co9S8/C can provide numerous active sites for rapid Li+ conduction, suppresses lithium dendrite growth and enhance battery safety. The internally polar Co9S8 and carbon matrix can enhance the conductivity of the modified separator as a “second current collector” and further adsorb and catalyze soluble LPSs, improving the utilization of active materials. Additionally, the stable hollow structure of MoS2/Co9S8/C also can be acted as a “transfer station” and greatly suppressed the massive loss of LiPSs. Therefore, the prepared MoS2/Co9S8/C not only significantly enhanced the adsorption-catalytic effect on LPSs, improving reaction kinetics, but also effectively facilitated lithium ions conduction. The dual advantages of structure and composition made the modified separator exhibit excellent performance at different current densities. Zinc sulfide (ZnS) exhibits strong catalytic ability towards LiPSs, while tin sulfide (SnS) as a semiconductor material with a narrow band-gap offers better conductivity. Yao et al. [153] combined the advantages of SnS’s strong adsorption and high conductivity with ZnS’s excellent catalytic ability to obtain a uniform cubic-shaped N-doped carbon shell-coated ZnS-SnS heterostructure (ZnS-SnS@NC) (Fig. 16D). The prepared heterostructure was loaded onto the separator of LSBs as a functional layer to suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSs and enable uniform lithium deposition. By optimizing ZnS-SnS@NC, a well-dispersed ZnS-SnS heterostructure with abundant active sites at the heterointerfaces can be achieved. The prepared ZnS exhibited excellent catalytic ability towards LiPSs, while the formed SnS also provided high conductivity and strong adsorption. The presence of the interfaces ensured sufficient electrochemical active sites, facilitating rapid electron transfer and improving the electrochemical performance of sulfur cathodes and lithium anodes. Additionally, the ZnS-SnS@NC matrix can be acted as an ion sieve, enabling the uniform redistribution of Li+ flux and promoting homogeneous lithium deposition. Thus, the assembled LSBs based on the ZnS-SnS@NC separators demonstrated stable sulfur electrochemistry including high reversible capacity, good rate performance, long cycling life and competitive areal capacity under high sulfur loading. Bimetallic sulfides can be served as excellent modification materials for lithium-sulfur battery separators. They generally possess high ion conductivity, which accelerates the diffusion rate of lithium ions in the battery and improves the battery’s charge-discharge performance. Some researchers are currently focusing on the structural and functional design of bimetallic sulfides. Structural design aims to increase the exposure ratio of the modified material, thereby enhancing the number of active sites. Moreover, functional design revolves around constructing synergistic “adsorption-catalysis” sites to achieve rapid conversion of LiPSs, thereby suppressing the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and accelerating their reaction kinetics. Clearly, utilizing compounds with two different functionalities to construct heterogeneous interfaces is an effective strategy to achieve these goals. 3.3.4 Bimetallic phosphides Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have been proposed as promising mediators for LiPSs conversion in high-energy LSBs due to their strong adsorption and rapid conversion capabilities. When compared to metal oxides and sulfides, TMPs exhibit metallic properties and excellent conductivity, making them suitable LiPSs intermediates which combine outstanding LiPSs affinity with high Li+ flux. Wu et al. [154] implanted the Ni/Co bimetallic phosphides into a hollow carbon nano-cage (Ni-Co-P@C) and used it as a multi-functional intermediate layer in the separator (Fig. 16B). The outer carbon layer of the hollow nanocage can provide a physical constraint for LiPSs diffusion, while Li+ ions can migrate rapidly through the porous carbon layer to facilitate LiPSs conversion. The embedded polar Ni-CoP nanoparticles effectively capture LiPSs and can be served as catalytic active sites for promoting LiPSs conversion. The high conductivity of carbon and TMPs also can enhance the electron transfer capability and improve the kinetics of redox reactions, particularly beneficial for utilizing active sulfur at high current rates. Thanks to the unique hollow nanocage structure and abundant synergistic adsorption-electrocatalytic sites, the assembled LSBs using Ni-Co-P@C separators achieved exceptional stability in terms of lifespan. Compared to catalysts with 2D and 3D structures, it is crucial to fabricate 1D catalysts with high specific surface area and fast Li+ transport capability. Wang et al. [155] designed and prepared a multifunctional nanocomposite material consisting of cobalt-doped molybdenum phosphide (Co-MoP) nanofibers and porous carbon nanofibers (PCNFs) through electrospinning way and phosphidation process (Fig. 16C). The prepared Co-MoP nanofibers can provide high surface area and strong polar surface affinity, with multiple adsorption and catalytic sites, effectively capturing LiPSs and promoting the conversion of LiPSs to Li2S2/Li2S.
