Firstly, introducing cobalt Co into MoP nanofibers imparted sufficient adsorption catalytic sites, convenient mass transfer pathways, reduced charge transfer resistance and optimized Gibbs free energy, promoting fast spontaneous reactions of intermediates. Secondly, the obtained Co-MoP nanofibers provided sufficient interfaces to chemically anchor intermediate LiPSs and further facilitated the conversion of LiPSs into insoluble Li2S2/Li2S and solid-phase S8, thereby suppressing their shuttle effect. Thirdly, the abundant and interconnected pore structure of PCNFs also can provide enough space to accommodate the significant volume changes during cycling. The combination of N-doped PCNFs and Co-MoP nanofibers can synergistically enhance fast electron transfer and catalytic conversion of LiPSs. The obtained PCNFs modified with the pyridine-N and pyrrole-N can accelerate the redox reactions at the interface between the cathode and functional separator, tending to inhibit the shuttle effect of LiPSs during cycle process. Therefore, the composite material assembled with the Co-MoP nanofibers and PCNF-modified separator in high performance LSBs exhibited excellent long-cycle performance. As a modifier for the separators of LSBs, bimetallic phosphides exhibit outstanding affinity for LiPSs and rapid Li+ conduction. The composite material formed by combining bimetallic phosphides with high-surface-area conductive carbon materials can greatly leverage the advantages of both materials and synergistically enhance the performance of LSBs. The detailed information of Li-S batteries with the separators using bimetallic sulfides and phosphides is presented in Table S10, which will provide some guidances for further researching them in high performance LSBs. 3.3.5 Bimetallic carbides Metal carbides have gained widespread attention in the field of materials science due to their high conductivity and excellent performance. Bimetallic carbides not only exhibit better catalytic effects than that of monometallic carbides, but also reduce the migration barrier of lithium ions, promoting their fast transfer and demonstrating higher catalytic performance in redox reactions. Hong et al. [156] developed a separator by coating the Ni3ZnC0.7/Ni/NCNTs, namely by dispersing bimetallic carbide nanoparticles based on Ni3ZnC0.7 in a N-doped porous carbon material matrix containing a small amount of Ni metal particles (Fig. 17 A). The prepared Ni3ZnC0.7 possessed sulfur-affinitive sites from Ni and lithium-affinitive sites from Zn, resulting in faster lithium ions diffusion and more effective catalytic capability towards LiPSs. When used as a separator coating for LSBs, the Ni3ZnC0.7 bimetallic carbide exhibited efficient adsorption and catalytic action on LiPSs, suppressing the shuttle effect of LiPSs and improving the electrochemical performance of the battery. Rapid electron transfer between metal active sites with different oxidation states enables researchers to modulate the conversion kinetics of LiPSs by adjusting the oxidation states of metal active sites. Modulation and optimization of metal active sites in high-performance electrocatalysts can be achieved by introducing specific edge, vacancy and dopant atoms. Yang et al. [157] selected hollow carbon-encapsulated Ni3ZnC0.7 nanospheres (C/Ni3ZnC0.7) with bimetallic active sites as an electrocatalyst for modifying commercial PP separators (Fig. 17B). Furthermore, to tune the electronic state and electrocatalytic activity of the metal active sites, the phosphorus-doped (P-doped) C/Ni3ZnC0.7 nanospheres and Ni vacancies were separately introduced to obtain P-doped C/Ni3ZnC0.7 nanospheres. The formed P-doping and Ni vacancy imparted abundant defects and distortions to the C/Ni3ZnC0.7 nanospheres, exposing rich catalytic active sites. However, they modulated the oxidation states of the metal active sites in different ways. The prepared P-doping and the accompanying Zn vacancies significantly reduced the electron density of Zn active sites in the C/Ni3ZnC0.7. In addition, Ni vacancies increased the content of Ni2+ in C/Ni3ZnC0.7 nanospheres. Optimizing Zn sites can anchor LiPSs and be served as reservoirs to help modulate the oxidation states of Ni active sites. Therefore, the prepared C/Ni3ZnC0.7 with a higher concentration of Ni2+ species exhibited strong chemical adsorption capability towards LiPSs and catalytic ability to accelerate the conversion kinetics of LiPSs. When the C/Ni3ZnC0.7 nanospheres were used to modify PP separators commonly employed in LSBs, the batteries showed excellent rate performance and cycling stability. Bimetallic carbide Co3Mo3C provides more adsorption sites for LiPSs and catalytic sites for sulfur/LiPSs/sulfide phase conversion compared to monometallic carbide Mo2C. Zhang et al. [158] designed and synthesized molybdenum bimetallic carbide (Co3Mo3C) encapsulated in a hybrid microporous/low-range mesoporous carbon support as an effective electrocatalyst for separator modification to enhance the electrochemical performance of the assembled LSBs (Fig. 17D). The prepared carbon-supported Co3Mo3C nanocrystals had an average size of 3–5 nm. Compared to monometallic carbide Mo2C, the bimetallic carbide Co3Mo3C exhibited the significantly enhanced catalytic activity towards the redox kinetics of LiPSs due to multiple binding sites for LiPSs. Furthermore, the catalytically modified separator demonstrated excellent mechanical strength, enabling increased reuse cycles and delivering LSBs assembled with metal carbide catalysts with high sulfur utilization and prolonged cycling life. Mo and W are elements of the same group, exhibiting similar chemical properties. Zhao et al. [159] successfully prepared Co3W3C@C composite material using a simple one-step pyrolysis method. They employed a Co3W3C@C-coated separator as a novel catalytic film can enhance the electrochemical performance of LSBs (Fig. 17C). The intermediate layer of Co3W3C@C, which had a high carbon content, not only improved the electronic conductivity for rapid electron transfer, but also can be acted as a physical barrier to prevent the shuttle of LiPSs. Additionally, the Co3W3C nanoparticles, through strong chemical interactions, can provide abundant sites for absorbing dissolved LiPSs and catalyzing the redox reactions of sulfur species. The assembled LSBs with the Co3W3C@C catalytic separator demonstrated excellent cycling performance and rate capability. Bimetallic carbides provide more adsorption sites for sulfides and catalytic conversion of sulfur/LiPSs/sulfides compared to single-metal carbides. The catalytic activity for the redox kinetics of sulfide oxidation is also significantly enhanced due to the increased number of binding sites. However, the full utilization of these active sites requires well-developed modulation strategies. In this regard, many researchers have employed vacancy and heteroatom doping as modulation and optimization methods for the active sites of dual-metal carbides. By adjusting the pore structure and size distribution of dual-metal carbides, the pathways and transport rate of lithium ions can be controlled to optimize ion diffusion and penetration performance. In addition, surface modification of bimetallic carbides, such as introducing functional groups or coating with conductive materials, can enhance the interface affinity between the material and the electrolyte, thereby improving ion conductivity. The detailed information of Li-S batteries with the separators using bimetallic carbides is presented in Table S11, which will provide researchers more suggestions for further improving the electrochemical performance of LSBs. 3.3.6 Others Metal nitrides have been proven to exhibit excellent catalytic performance in the rapid conversion of short-chain LiPSs to long-chain LiPSs. This conversion helps prevent hindrance of charge transfer, reduces self-discharge phenomena and partially suppresses “shuttle effect“ of LiPSs. Zhang et al. [160] proposed an in-situ external metal etching strategy to activate inert single-metal nitrides through doping methods (Fig. 18 A). They modified the separator using a Ni0.2Mo0.8N/MWCNT composite material to achieve dual functionality of adsorption and catalysis. The construction of the functional layer on the separator led to an internal electric field directed towards the anode. The creation of this internal electric field facilitated the movement of ions, thereby reducing the dissolution of LiPSs. Since molybdenum (compared to nickel) was more positive at the corners, it was easily etched out by LiPSs, leaving behind abundant pore defects to activate it. The introduction of molybdenum (Mo) altered the position of the d-band compared to Ni3N. It also enhanced the delocalization of electrons, widened the lattice spacing, and provided good conductivity and catalytic performance to the LiPSs. Meanwhile, MWCNT was used to form an interlaced 3D network structure which created internal conductive pathways and accelerated electron transfer. By utilizing the advantages mentioned above, using the prepared Ni0.2Mo0.8N/MWCNT as the functional layer for modified separators can achieve good surface stress and strong mechanical properties. More importantly, it retained the original properties of the separator while achieving dual catalytic and adsorption effects on LiPSs. Surface defect engineering tunes the electronic structure of materials and plays an important role in promoting conductivity and charge transfer dynamics. Metal selenides possess abundant selenium vacancies, and Co and Fe elements exhibit excellent catalytic performance for LSBs. Kang et al. [161] designed and prepared defect structures using Co and Fe elements and successfully synthesized 3D network-structured bimetallic selenide nanocubes (Co9Se8- x /FeSe2- y @CNTs) with Se vacancies, which were used for separator modification in LSBs (Fig. 18C). The selenium vacancies on the surface of Co9Se8- x /FeSe2- y can provide more active sites for binding with LiPSs and facilitate Li+ diffusion. Additionally, the CNTs possessed a large specific surface area and high conductivity, providing sufficient space for interface reactions and enhancing the conductivity of the composite material. More importantly, there was a synergistic effect between Co9Se8- x /FeSe2- y and CNTs, which collaboratively promoted the adsorption and catalytic reaction kinetics of sulfur and LiPSs. The Co9Se8- x /FeSe2- y @CNTs/PP modified separator exhibited a highly synergistic triple function of adsorption, barrier and catalysis for LiPSs. The prepared Co9Se8- x /FeSe2- y @CNTs//PP cell demonstrated excellent cycling stability under high sulfur loading and low electrolyte-to-sulfur ratio (E/S). Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) composed of metal ions and organic ligands exhibit adsorption and catalytic activity towards LiPSs. By further manipulating their structure, such as introducing defects and adjusting the metal centers, the synergistic effects of adsorption and catalysis can be effectively altered. Zhou et al. [162] prepared 2D bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF nanosheets as functional modification layers for PP separators (Fig. 18B). The obtained ZIF-67 with a Co metal center showed better catalytic performance towards LiPSs, promoting their rapid conversion. In addition, the ZIF-8 with a Zn metal center exhibited higher binding affinity towards soluble long-chain LiPSs, enabling more efficient adsorption. The Zn and Co metal centers were individually beneficial for the adsorption and catalysis of LiPSs, but ZIFs with only Zn or Co metal centers were not able to effectively trap and convert LiPSs. Therefore, by adjusting the ratio of Zn and Co metal center sites in the Zn/Co-ZIF, synergistic adsorption and catalysis of LiPSs can be achieved. Additionally, based on the difference in conductivity between the ZIF modification layer and the cathode, continuous and efficient conversion, as well as directed deposition of LiPSs towards the cathode, can be achieved. The results demonstrated that the assembled LSBs with the ZIF-B@PP separators had the improved electrochemical performance. The detailed information of LSBs with the separators using bimetallic nitrides, selenides and ZIFs is presented in Table S12, which will help people to further improve these materials in the future for further improving the electrochemical performance of the battery. In terms of separators, the main focuses of bimetallic modified materials are to optimize the safety and stability of Li-S batteries. The role of separators in Li-S batteries is to isolate the cathode and anode electrode, prevent direct electron conduction and allow Li+ transport. The goal of modified separators is to improve their thermal stability, mechanical strength, puncture resistance and reduce impedance. Currently, there are several strategies for separator modification need be paid attention: (1) Introducing polarity adsorbents to immobilize free LiPSs. (2) Adding conductive surfaces on the separator to enhance electrochemical reaction activity and improve the utilization of active materials. (3) Introducing catalytic functionality to accelerate LiPSs reaction kinetics. (4) Using negatively charged polarity materials to repel the diffusion of LiPSs towards the anode side. (5) Optimizing the interface between the separator and the anode to improve the stability of the lithium anode interfaces. Bimetallic are used as functional coatings to prevent the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. By controlling the surface properties and interface interactions of bimetallic materials, better isolation and ion transport control can be achieved, thereby improving battery performance. 3.4 Self-supporting interlayers On the cathode side, in addition to the modified layer dependent on the separator, there are currently some independent self-supporting interlayers being studied. These prepared interlayers can enhance the transport of lithium ions and electrons as well as the mechanical properties of the materials. When designing the layered structure of battery materials, some researchers also utilize interlayers as connecting layers between the cell cathode and separator, providing electronic transport paths and improving the adhesion and electrical contact between the active material and current collector, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance and safety of the battery. Various carefully designed nanostructured carbon materials have been employed as interlayers. However, the nonpolar-polar interactions between carbon materials and LiPSs, mediated by van der Waals forces, are not sufficient to impart satisfactory electrochemical performance to LSBs. Given the slow redox kinetics during the multistep transition of LiPSs, several polar metal compounds such as transition metal sulfides, oxides, nitrides and carbides have been incorporated into the interlayers to promote anchoring capability and chemical affinity towards LiPSs [163]. It is noteworthy that metal catalysts with Lewis acidic matrices, often serving as active sites, anchor sulfur species and accelerate the reaction kinetics during complex redox processes. Conceptually, the construction of uniformly distributed and abundant active sites is crucial for enhancing the immobilization of metal-based electrocatalysts in the LiPSs and their electrocatalytic activity during the redox conversion process. Mixtures of transition metals and conductive matrix materials have been demonstrated to exhibit effectively chemical affinity towards LiPSs and improved redox kinetics. Therefore, for Li-S batteries, the interlayers constructed from bimetallic materials serves as a structural barrier to effectively restrict the flow of LiPSs towards the anode. Additionally, it acts as micro-cavities for the conversion reaction, anchoring the dissolved LiPSs in an enclosed space to enhance their adsorption and conversion efficiency. This interlayer structure provides numerous opportunities to suppress the “shuttle effect” and enhance the sluggish sulfur conversion kinetics. The application of carbonaceous scaffold-supported bimetallic polar materials as an intermediate layer can effectively enhance the long-cycle lifespan of LSBs. Adjusting the band structure of metal sulfides is a pathway to enhance their catalytic activity. Liu et al. [164] proposed a conductive sulfur-affinitive barrier with a large-area nanostructured NiCo2S4@CT interlayer to promote the redox kinetics of soluble LiPSs. The large-area mesoporous NiCo2S4 nanosheets provided strong chemical bonding for LiPSs, acting as a chemical barrier to mitigate the shuttle effect of LiPSs. Furthermore, it also enhanced the ion transfer kinetics at the NiCo2S4-LiPSs interfaces, exhibiting effective catalytic activity for accelerating the LiPSs redox reactions. The nanoscale thickness also can ensure rapid redox kinetics. Therefore, the NiCo2S4@CT interlayer ensured low polarization and high Coulombic efficiency, particularly effective for achieving high rate and long-cycle performance. Heterostructures can adjust the band structure of metal sulfides to enhance catalytic activity. Heterostructures also can be formed by coupling two metal sulfides with appropriate band gaps. Co9S8 possesses metallic properties (136 S cm−1) and can accelerate electron transfer. Li et al. [165] prepared a core-shell heterostructure of Co9S8@MoS2 anchored on carbon nanofibers (Co9S8@MoS2/CNF) for adsorbing and catalyzing sulfur species in rechargeable LSBs (Fig. 19 A). In this structure, the band structure of MoS2 was well-adjusted by growing it on the Co9S8 core, providing a synergistic relationship between adsorption and catalysis, effectively suppressing the shuttle effect of LiPSs and enhancing the electrochemical redox reactions of LiPSs. The first-principles calculations also demonstrated that heterostructures can effectively reduce the dissociation energy of Li2S2, promote the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S, and significantly improve the sulfur utilization on high-sulfur-loaded electrodes in LSBs. Additionally, the applied CNF possessed high porosity and permeability, allowing for the adsorption of a large amount of liquid electrolyte and providing effective conduction pathways. The synergistic interactions among the constituents within the Co9S8@MoS2/CNF can significantly enhance the overall performance of LSBs. Bimetallic sulfides with a pyrite structure have been found to exhibit excellent catalytic activity in the electrochemical reduction of LiPSs when compared to monometallic sulfides. The Co–S and Fe–S bonds have been proven to have better binding energy and charge transfer with LiPSs. Huang et al. [166] demonstrated that bimetallic sulfides with a Co–Fe molar ratio of 2:1 exhibited a pyrite phase, showing strong chemical bonding and catalytic conversion capability. The Co and Fe ions in CFS-2/CP exhibited charge synergy and balance their electronic structure and local electron cloud density, thereby adjusting the overall binding energy towards LiPSs. The bimetallic sulfides on the CFS-2/CP interlayer exhibited strong mechanical adhesion, and the Co and Fe ions worked synergistically to enhance chemical capture capability and accelerate the redox conversion of LiPSs. Furthermore, the application of bimetallic sulfides as the intermediate layer can effectively accelerate electrons and ions transfer, when compared to monometallic sulfides providing better cycling performance. Therefore, the utilization of CFS-2/CP interlayer in LSBs had achieved significant cycling stability. Transition metal-based alloys (TMAs) are considered to have high activity, strong stability and good selectivity. Compared to single metals, the alloying of two metals converts weak metal-carbon interactions into synergistic metal-metal interactions, optimizing the electronic structure of the catalyst and enhancing its catalytic activity. The atomic and ionic radii of iron and cobalt are close to each other, making it easy to form a Co-Fe solid solution during synthesis, thus avoiding phase separation issues. Gao et al. [167] successfully prepared Co x Fe y @CNFs functional interlayers with multiple adsorption/catalytic sites (Fig. 19D). The 3D carbon network derived from bacterial cellulose pyrolysis not only facilitated the in-situ reduction of metal ions to metals, but also restricted the particle size of Co x Fe y nanoparticles. While the metal alloy promoted the carbon graphitization. The combination of well-dispersed alloy nanoparticles and the 3D carbon network significantly reduced the contact resistance. It not only allowed efficient contact of soluble LiPSs through the 3D structure of the carbon network, but also accelerated the redox kinetics during the conversion process. Moreover, the synergistic catalytic effect between Co and Fe species resulted in excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. The prepared CoFe@CNFs exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity and the catalytic interlayer also can provide satisfactory rate and cycling performance. Importantly, even at a temperature as low as 0 °C, LSBs with the interlayer can still undergo normal charge-discharge cycles and exhibit acceptable discharge capacity, indicating good rate dynamics. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) exhibit certain catalytic activity and chemical adsorption capacity. For LSBs, hollow and porous TMP interlayers can achieve effective adsorption of LiPSs through the precise nanoscale structural design. Wang et al. [168] designed and prepared a hollow nickel-cobalt bimetallic phosphide nanocage (NiCoP) (Fig. 19B), which mainly consisted of interconnected nanosheets on the outer and inner shells and can be served as an interlayer for achieving a closed reactor for LiPSs. Its unique microstructure also can provide abundant adsorption and electrocatalytic active sites. The hollow closed reactor enhanced the capture efficiency of LiPSs, achieved strong immobilization of LiPSs, improved sulfur utilization and enabled rapid and persistent sulfur electrochemistry. The rational interlayer design may offer a new perspective for designing effective LiPSs closed reactors for high-performance LSBs using the interlayer. The electron transfer between metal species with different valence states can balance the adsorption/desorption energy barriers of LSBs intermediates in multiple electrocatalytic reaction pathways. The rational adjustment of the valence states of the coordination unsaturated metal active centers is an available strategy to modulate the electronic properties and catalytic activity of electrocatalysts. The reasonable valence state engineering of the active metal centers through cation modulation can precisely tune the catalytic activity of the electrocatalyst towards multi-electron transfer processes. Equally important, well-defined surface nanostructures and unique porosity are crucial for increasing exposed active sites and promoting charge transfer and mass transport of metal compound electrocatalysts to enhance their electroactivity. Wang et al. [169] prepared a zinc-modulated bimetallic carbide electrocatalyst (Co3ZnC@NC) by using dicyandiamide as a carbon/nitrogen precursor, anchoring it into 3D macroporous N-doped carbon embedded carbon microspheres (Fig. 19C). The 3D macroporous N-doped carbon matrix in Co3ZnC@NC interlayer can provide good conductivity, rapid liquid electrolyte penetration, and mass transport. At the same time, the embedded bimetallic carbide/carbon microspheres enable sufficient chemical adsorption and electroactive sites to rapidly sequester/adsorb LiPSs and effectively accelerate the redox kinetics of LiPSs. Interestingly, the Zn2+ species can modulate the balance of Co2+/Co0 pairs to ensure efficient electrocatalysis of Co2+ active centers. These advantages made the obtained Co3ZnC@NC interlayer exhibit excellent electrocatalytic performance when used in LSBs. Inserting a barrier layer between the cathode and the separator to intercept diffusing LiPSs is an effective approach to improve the electrochemical performance of LSBs. However, considering that the additional interlayer in the system inevitably increases weight and weakens the energy density advantage of the battery, it is crucial to develop an effective yet lightweight interlayer. Feng et al. [170] reported a 2D, ultra-thin, and ultra-light bimetallic NiCo-organic framework (MOF) as an interlayer for LSBs. The prepared interlayer had a thickness of only 1 μm, with nanometer-thick MOF nanosheets possessing a large specific surface area and abundant exposed accessible active sites. Meanwhile, due to the synergistic effect of the mixed metals and the unique coordination environment surrounding the active sites, the intrinsic activity of each site can be enhanced, leading to improved catalytic performance. CNTs construct a conductive network to enhance electronic conductivity while preventing the migration of LiPSs as a physical barrier. Therefore, the assembled battery with the 2D NiCo-MOF/CNT interlayer exhibited the strongest cycling stability and the lowest capacity decay rate among these samples. In the self-supporting interlayers, the introduction of bimetallic materials can increase the mechanical strength and chemical stability of the battery, enhancing its safety and reliability. The combination of bimetallic materials with other functional materials such as nanoclusters and polymer matrices also can form a multi-layered structure, providing excellent conductivity, mechanical support and Li+ transport channels for LSBs. It is important to note that interlayers and separators play different roles in lithium-sulfur batteries, complementing each other. Interlayer materials are primarily used to greatly improve the performance of the electrode interface, while separators are primarily used to prevent short circuits and provide ion transport channels. Interlayers are mainly used to facilitate the diffusion of lithium ions and charge transfer, assisting in controlling the deposition and diffusion of sulfides into the electrolyte, preventing direct contact of sulfides, and reducing the electrochemical reaction impedance between the cathode and anode electrodes. Interlayers of LSBs are typically porous materials, such as carbon nanotubes or porous carbon. Well-designed interlayers can prevent polarization phenomena and enhance the cycling stability of the battery. Interlayers can also increase the energy density of LSBs by increasing the effective reaction surface area of the electrode. However, the addition of interlayers can increase the volume and mass of the battery, as well as production costs, which can be disadvantageous for large-scale production and application. Therefore, the specific selection of interlayers in battery design and practical application needs to consider factors such as battery performance, cost, and reliability comprehensively. The detailed information of LSBs with the separators using bimetallic compound is presented in Table S13, which will provide some guidances for further researching them in high performance LSBs. In general, bimetallic alloys typically exhibit good electrical conductivity and cycling stability, which mainly are contributed to the improved discharge performance of batteries. Transition metal oxides usually possess stable structures, high specific surface areas and strong metal-oxygen bonds. Thus, bimetallic oxides often exhibit enhanced adsorption capabilities for anchoring LiPSs, thus effectively mitigating the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. However, these materials also usually have low electrical conductivity and huge limitations in catalyzing LiPSs. Therefore, in the adsorption-catalysis synergistic system, enhancing the adsorption capability of these transition metal oxides may be the key to improving performance. Of course, some well-designed bimetallic oxides can also exhibit electrocatalytic activities. Some spinel-type oxides (e.g., NiFe2O4, NiCo2O4 and ZnCo2O4) have been extensively studied due to their crystalline phases, which can effectively provide sturdy structures, accommodated huge volume changes and strong electrochemical properties. Among them, NiCo2O4 usually exhibits inherent polarity, allowing its surface metals or oxygen ions to interact synergistically with S x 2− and Li+, immobilize LiPSs shuttling and provide electrocatalytic activity. Moreover, NiCo2O4 also possesses remarkable electronic conductivity, which is at least two orders of magnitude higher than these of nickel oxide and cobalt oxide. NiFe2O4 is naturally abundant and environmentally-friendly, and the nanostructured NiFe2O4 also can achieve higher electrochemical activity through enhancing or modifying the interaction between Ni and Fe. For ZnCo2O4, it also has a well-defined structure, and Zn2+ maintains a constant oxidation state, resulting in exceptional stability for the composite. These characteristics make them promising candidates as main materials in Li-S battery cathodes. Oxygen, sulfur and selenium belong to the same group, so certain physicochemical properties of bimetallic oxides, sulfides and selenides are similar to a certain extent. However, metal-sulfur and metal-selenium bonds are weaker than metal-oxygen bonds, making bimetallic sulfides and selenides more efficient catalysts than those of their respective oxides. The obtained result can enhance the deposition behavior of Li2S2/Li2S and improves the kinetics of Li-S batteries. NiCo2S4 is a representative bimetallic sulfide material with abundant active sites, exhibiting strong electrochemical activity. Although bimetallic sulfides have better conductivity than these of single metal sulfides, poor overall conductivity remains a weakness for bimetallic sulfides. Therefore, current researches mainly focus on designing nanostructures or combining bimetallic sulfides with carbon materials with high electron conductivity to enhance the conductivity of the composites. Transition metal nitrides have strong catalytic abilities for LiPSs conversion. Compared to sulfides, nitrides have the advantage of high conductivity, enabling fast electron transfer and improved electrochemical utilization of active sulfur. Additionally, bimetallic nitrides usually exhibit high catalytic efficiency, inducing rapid conversion of LiPSs and alleviating their aggregation, thus producing more active sites. However, bimetallic nitrides and sulfides usually show weak adsorption capabilities towards LiPSs. Bimetallic carbides have significantly higher conductivity than bimetallic oxides, but their interaction with LiPSs is relatively weak, leading to unsatisfactory shuttle suppression. Bimetallic phosphides possess better conductivity, with some even exhibiting superconductivity, which benefits the kinetics of redox reactions and effectively enhances sulfur utilization. However, the application of metal phosphides is limited by their low surface area and sulfur loading. Effective affinity towards LiPSs is crucial for mitigating the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Some materials with excessive adsorption capacity can hinder the formation of Li2S n (n = 4–8) species and slow down the reaction rate. Overall, bimetallic oxides, carbides and phosphides have suitable adsorption capabilities but lower catalytic abilities. However, bimetallic sulfides, selenides and nitrides exhibit relatively strong catalytic performances, but they also have potential drawbacks. Each type of metal compound has its advantages and disadvantages. Hence, when designing bimetallic materials, the application scenario should be considered to design and synthesize suitable products. Fe, Co, and Ni also are all effective single-atom catalysts and are widely designed for high-performance Li-S batteries. Based on these researches their alloys or compounds composed of these elements typically exhibit synergistically enhanced catalytic performance. Common combinations include NiCo oxides, NiCo sulfides, NiFe oxides, NiCo phosphides, and CoFe alloys, etc. On the other hand, metals such as Zn, Cu, Mo, Ti and V also have good lithium affinity, and some of their compounds (e.g., ZnS, MoS2, TiN and VN) usually demonstrate excellent adsorption properties. While current researches mainly focus on catalyst development, combining metal compounds with strong adsorption properties and transition metal compounds with high catalytic performance to form bimetallic materials with a synergistic “adsorption-catalysis” effect may also be a promising synthesis strategy. 4 Conclusions and perspectives In recent years, significant research progresses have been made in the application of bimetallic materials to suppress the shuttle effect and accelerate the reaction kinetics in LSBs. The review provides an overview of the large achievements in the application of bimetallic materials in the cathode, separator and interlayer, summarizing and discussing the key parameters related to the rate capability and cycling performance of LSBs. In the kind of the battery, the slow conversion between soluble LiPSs and insoluble Li2S2/Li2S is the main cause of the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs in the liquid electrolyte, which severely reduces the energy efficiency and cycling performance of the battery. Therefore, an ideal sulfur host should not only have a strong affinity for LiPSs, but also promote the mutual conversion of LiPSs and Li2S2/Li2S, which is considered a feasible strategy to inhibit the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Bimetallic alloys and compounds with good conductivity and adsorption-catalytic ability facilitate lithium ions transport and strong interaction with LiPSs, demonstrating higher energy density, improved cycling stability and excellent Coulombic efficiency. For achieving better electrochemical performance, some researchers have developed modified cathodes, separators and interlayers using bimetallic alloys and compounds with different structures and morphologies to restrict LiPSs shuttling and subsequent catalytic conversion. These bimetallic materials mainly include bimetallic alloys, bimetallic oxides, bimetallic sulfides, bimetallic phosphides, bimetallic carbides, bimetallic nitrides and bimetallic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and their composites. To be brief, inherent conductivity and strong catalytic ability of bimetallic alloys and compounds are advantageous for Li+ transport and their interactions with LiPSs. Accelerating the surface redox reactions of bimetallic compounds is also crucial for reducing energy barriers and improving battery performance. Enhancing the conversion rate between adsorbed LiPSs and insoluble Li2S2/Li2S also is key to effectively suppressing the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Combining methods having catalytic effects and physically/chemically adsorb LiPSs is an effective approach to address LiPSs shuttling, and this hold promise as an efficient solution for developing high-performance and practical LSBs. However, there are still some challenges to be addressed for the commercial application of bimetallic materials in high-performance LSBs. Firstly, the design and fabrication of bimetallic materials require precise control of their compositions, structures, morphologies, as well as interface compatibilities and coupling effects with other components, to achieve optimal catalytic performance. Secondly, the long-term stability and durability of bimetallic materials need to be further improved to meet the requirements of practical applications. In addition, cost-effectiveness and scalability are also key factors driving the commercial application of bimetallic materials. Future researching directions mainly include the development of novel bimetallic materials, optimization of their structure and composition, to further enhance the performance and stability of LSBs. At the same time, a deeper understanding of the interaction mechanisms between bimetallic materials and LiPSs is needed, along with systematic characterization and modeling studies to guide material design and optimization. Furthermore, exploration of innovative electrolyte systems, interface engineering and battery architectures is necessary to address the challenges in the commercialization of LSBs and promote their widespread use in the field of energy storage. The design of bimetallic materials should further be considered the adsorption affinity, electrical conductivity, and Li+ diffusion rate with LiPSs. Starting from the design of metal compound composites with rich porous structures, the specific conversion effects of LiPSs can be studied through in-situ observation, reaction mechanism analysis and corresponding theoretical calculations, in order to design sulfur host materials with high electrochemical activity. These suggestions (Fig. 20 ) summarized here can provide deeper insights and approaches for the development of bimetallic materials related to high performance LSBs: (1) For facilitating the adsorption-diffusion-conversion processes of LiPSs and effectively stabilize and accelerate the redox reactions of sulfur species, it also is rather advantageous to design bimetallic alloys or compounds with both “strong adsorption” and “high catalytic” properties. The obtained results would enable the realization of long-lasting LSBs with long lifespan. (2) To confine the reactions of S and LiPSs within a restricted space, it is beneficial to design hollow encapsulated or porous semi-encapsulated structures. Some examples include hollow yolk-shell structures, hollow nano-cages, hollow microtubes, and semi-enclosed porous carbon nanofibers can be considered. (3) The development of novel bimetallic species may lead to unexpected synergistic effects based on the advanced materials technology and suitable for large-scale and rapid production (4) High conductivity and ion transport: Rapid migration and coupling of ions and electrons directly affect the conversion reaction kinetics of LiPSs. Therefore, modified materials should facilitate ion migration on the surface of cell materials. Furthermore, due to the poor conductivity of S8 and Li2S2/Li2S, highly conductive modified materials can improve the utilization of active materials and reduce polarization in the battery. (5) Minimizing the proportion of inert components in the battery structure: Electrochemically inert sulfur hosts not only dilute the content of electrochemically active sulfur materials in the cathode and introduce additional manufacturing costs, but also often result in a high porosity and low density. However, materials with low density are difficult to achieve high areal loading, while excessively dense electrode structures lead to lower E/S ratios and a reduction in the migration of LiPSs and charge transfer capability of the electrolyte. Therefore, an optimal point is required to maximize energy density. (6) Sufficient mechanical stability: Modifying materials should possess sufficient mechanical stability to enhance practicality and simultaneously regulate the stress generated from the huge volume changes of sulfur materials during charge and discharge processes. (7) High specific surface area: High specific surface area modified materials expose enough active sites to enhance electrochemical activity and efficiency. This result not only reduces the weight of the sulfur host to improve the electrode energy density, but also provides a large surface area for the uniform adsorption of LiPSs and the deposition of discharge products Li2S2/Li2S. (8) Low cost and abundant sources: Considering the practical application of LSBs, the application of low-cost modified materials should be prioritized. Bimetallic materials not only accelerate the reaction kinetics of liquid-state Li-S batteries, but they are also expected to have unexpected effects and merits in solid-state Li-S batteries. The insolubility of LiPSs in solid electrolytes and the high shear modulus of solid electrolytes themselves make it possible to address the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and dendrite growth of lithium by using solid or quasi-solid electrolytes. However, in this fascinating field, there are still some issues which need to be addressed, such as limited space for accommodating the insoluble sulfides and stress generated during the volume change of the cathode electrode, poor interfaces between solid electrolytes and electrodes and sluggish reaction kinetics. The sluggish kinetics in solid-state Li-S batteries are mainly due to the slow reaction kinetics on the sulfur electrode. Some electrocatalysts also can promote reaction kinetics and improve the reaction rate of the electrode. Although solid-state Li-S batteries do not have intermediate reactions, there is still a process of sulfur species transforming into short-chain LiPSs, which is reversible during charge and discharge processes. A good electrocatalyst can accelerate this reversible conversion process. Therefore, the introductions of suitable bimetallic electrocatalysts in solid state Li-s batteries are expected to improve the energy density and charge-discharge efficiency of the batteries, thereby effectively addressing their kinetic issues. Although substantial progresses have been made in the development of bimetallic catalysts for promoting reaction kinetics, a comprehensive understanding of the S–S bond cleavage induced by bimetallic catalysts remains be unclear. Moreover, during the cycling process, sulfur species may accumulate on the catalyst surface, potentially affecting the catalyst’s activity. In order to obtain reliable conversion processes and establish a correct theory regarding sulfur oxidation-reduction, it is crucial to track the complete chemical reactions for the whole processes. Therefore, in the development of novel bimetallic materials, it is suggested to employ appropriate characterization techniques, such as in-situ Raman/TEM (transmission electron microscopy)/X-ray absorption fine structure, to observe the instantaneous changes during sulfur conversion processes. Many performance tests of bimetallic materials are conducted under laboratory conditions with low sulfur loading and a large number of liquid electrolytes. Considering the high sulfur loading and poor electrolyte conditions in practical applications, suppressing the intensified “shuttle effect” of LiPSs is also a challenging issue. Thus, it is necessary to strengthen the performance evaluation of LSBs with low E/S to meet the needs of practical applications. Furthermore, Li-S batteries encounter numerous actual challenges during their practical application, which are difficult to fully demonstrate in coin cells. Hence, it is essential to conduct additional investigations into the performance of bimetallic materials in pouch cells. These studies will contribute to obtaining more precise and dependable information for the practical utilization of high performance Li-S batteries. The performance of high-energy density Li-S pouch batteries is crucial for the commercialization of Li-S batteries. Bimetallic materials also play an important role in the design and fabrication of high-energy density Li-S pouch batteries. Among them, bimetallic materials with a core-shell structure may be a promising solution. The core-shell structure consists of a metal core and a shell loaded on the surface of the metal core. This structure combines the conductivity of the metal core with the chemical stability of the shell, thereby possessing excellent ion transport performance and electrochemical stability. Designing a core with strong adsorption and a shell with high catalytic activity is expected to construct a strong and stable “adsorption-catalysis” unit, effectively mitigating the shuttle effect and improving the stability and cycling life of Li-S batteries. Furthermore, by adjusting parameters such as the particle size, thickness, and composition of the core-shell structure, bimetallic materials can achieve better interface contact and ion transport efficiency, thereby significantly improving the battery’s power performance and reaction kinetics. All of these will provide a promising solution for practical high-energy density Li-S pouch batteries. It should be noted that practical high-energy density Li-S pouch batteries still face some technical challenges, such as the electrochemical reaction kinetics of sulfides and the optimization of electrode structures. Therefore, more researches and technological innovations are still needed to achieve the commercial application of high-performance Li-S pouch batteries. All in all, the paper discusses and investigates the development and application of bimetallic materials in LSBs in recent years. This review analyzes the strategies adopted by researchers to address challenging issues in LSBs and provides suggestions and approaches for preparing bimetallic materials for high performance LSBs. These findings will contribute to the solid foundation of new bimetallic materials researches and developments. We believe that with the rapid advancement of new technologies and equipment, the preparation of high-performance bimetallic materials will become more convenient, providing more opportunities for the fast developments and commercialization of high performance LSBs. Yongbing Jin received his Bachelor’s degree in Nonwoven Materials and Engineering from Tiangong University in 2022. He is currently pursuing a Master’s degree at Tiangong University. His research focuses on the modification of cathode materials and separators for high-performance lithium-sulfur batteries. His current main research direction involves utilizing electrospinning technology to prepare modified materials and applying them in lithium-sulfur batteries. Nanping Deng associate professor and doctoral supervisor of the School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tianjin Polytechnic University, is mainly engaged in the preparation of nanofiber materials and its application in the field of new energy. In terms of electrocatalysts, a series of nanofiber electrocatalysts have been prepared and modified, and the prepared electrocatalysts not only have excellent electrochemical properties, but also have impressive stability and practicality. He published 60 SCI papers as the first and corresponding author in ESM, AFM, Small, JEC and other journals, including 40 SCI papers in the first region, 25 papers with an impact factor greater than 10, and 4 papers were selected as ESI highly cited papers, with a total number of citations up to 3370 times and an h-index of 34. My doctoral thesis won the excellent doctoral thesis of China Textile Engineering Society and Tianjin Excellent doctoral thesis, and won the “Wang Shanyuan Excellent doctoral Fund”. Granted 10 patents, in 2021 and 2022 for two consecutive years in the “top 2% of the world's top scientists list”. Yanan Li received her bachelor’s degree in Textile Engineering, Tiangong University, China in 2021. Now, she is studying for a master’s degree at Tiangong University. Her research mainly concentrates on modification of high-performance lithium-sulfur batteries Hao Wang received a bachelor's degree in Textile Engineering from Hebei University of Science and Technology, China in 2021. Now, he is studying for a master's degree at Tiangong University. His main research direction is the preparation of separator modification materials for lithium-sulfur batteries by electrostatic solution blowing technology. He has published nearly 10 high-level articles in ESM, JMCA and other journals. Meiling Zhang has been working in Tiangong University, China since 2003, and obtained her doctoral degree in textile materials and textiles design from Tiangong University in 2011. She was appointed to vice professor in 2010. Her scientific interests are the preparation, modification and optimization of nanocellulose materials and their application in the fields of energy harvesting and storage, and oil-water separation etc. Weimin Kang has been working in Tiangong University, China since 2007, and obtained his doctoral degree in textile chemical engineering from Tiangong University in 2012. He was appointed to professor in 2017. His scientific interests are the design, preparation and evaluation of novel nanofibers and their application in storage areas such as fuel cells. In particular, he has conducted intensive research on the design and preparation of one-dimensional electrocatalysts. He won the national textile youth science and technology innovation leader, the first-level talent of Tianjin “131” innovative talent training project and the title of the first “Tianjin Youth Innovation Expert”, and won the 2018 Textile Youth Science and Technology Award and Baicao Fiber Textile Technology Achievement Transformation Promotion Award. And he was named into the World's Top 2% Scientists 2021. Bowen Cheng received his doctoral degree in Chemical Engineering from Tiangong University, China in 2003, and studied in Hochschule Niederrhein, Germany as a doctoral exchange student in 2001. Then he was appointed as a research associate at the University of Leeds, England. He is currently a professor in Tiangong University. His research focuses on novel fiber materials, advanced functional nonwovens and smart textiles for energy harvesting and storage.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered highly promising as next-generation energy storage systems due to high theoretical capacity (2600 W h kg−1) and energy density (1675 mA h g−1) as well as the abundant natural reserves, low cost of elemental sulfur, and environmentally friendly properties. However, several challenges impede its commercialization including low conductivity of sulfur itself, the severe “shuttle effect” caused by lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) during charge–discharge processes, volume expansion effects and sluggish reaction kinetics. As a solution, polar metal particles and their compounds have been introduced as the main hosts for sulfur cathode due to their robust catalytic activity and adsorption capability, effectively suppressing the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Bimetallic alloys and their compounds with multi-functional properties exhibit remarkable electrochemical performance more readily when compared to single-metal materials. Well-designed bimetallic materials demonstrate larger specific surface areas and richer active sites, enabling simultaneous high adsorption capability and strong catalytic properties. The synergistic effect of the “adsorption-catalysis” sites accelerates the adsorption-diffusion-conversion process of LiPSs, ultimately achieving a long-lasting Li-S battery. Herein, the latest progress and performance of bimetallic materials in cathodes, separators, and interlayers of Li-S batteries are systematically reviewed. Firstly, the principles and challenges of Li-S batteries are briefly analyzed. Then, various mechanisms for suppressing “shuttle effects” of LiPSs are emphasized at the microscale. Subsequently, the performance parameters of various bimetallic materials are comprehensively summarized, and some improvement strategies are proposed based on these findings. Finally, the future prospects of bimetallic materials are discussed, with the hope of providing profound insights for the rational design and manufacturing of high-performance bimetallic materials for LSBs.
